PS - this is probably one of the coolest awards ever to be given, we did it Andy Bouts !!! (Thanks again Ally)

It was an honor to help represent Comerica Bank in conjunction with Tech United and United Way for Southeastern Michigan as we collectively distributed another 220+ laptops to children in Detroit. Huge thank you to Anup Popat, Tonya Adair, Andre Ebron, MSOL, CDE, Levi Stubbs III for allowing me to be a part a amazing opportunity for the last 18 months. Thank you Bruce Mitchell for the constant and unrelenting support needed to achieve well over 1,000 devices since Comerica's inception of our program.

Tech United has an aspirational goal of conquering the digital divide in the Detroit area in which we believe the catalyst is getting a 1 to 1 ratio of computer to student which enables technology to be part of their everyday lives, not just a class in school or an assignment.

Thank you to Detroit Edison Public School Academy for allowing us to visit your beautiful school and interact with some of your students, meeting Dr. Bland was treat as well to hear the story of the building starting at a tomato plant and now the home for 1000+ scholars focused on their future and the future of the local community.

Thank you to follow Comerica colleagues for attending with me and supporting this effort Derek Calus, Audrey Sims-Carr, Ryan Smoyer, and Ryan Orkwis. We could never imagine doing this work at this scale without Derek and Audrey carrying the load each and ever day.

Happy to share that the rating agencies, Moody's Ratings’s and S&P Global Ratings, upgraded Fresenius Medical Care’s (FME) rating outlook to stable. Throughout 2023 and the first quarter of 2024, we have improved our operational and financial performance, strengthened our balance sheet, and delivered on our transformation program FME25. On the back of our progress, both rating agencies expect FME to maintain good growth momentum and continue to further improve operational performance.

With restoring our credit metrics and a stringent capital allocation policy, we are committed to maintain our investment grade rating, while continuing to execute on our mid-term plans.

Read more in our press release: https://lnkd.in/eaWsfSjC

#PressRelease #Rating #ProudToBeFME

Memorial Day, originally known as Decoration Day, was established after the American Civil War. The first widely recognized observance was on May 30, 1868, when Major General John A. Logan, leader of an organization for Northern Civil War veterans, called for a nationwide day of remembrance. On that day, Americans were encouraged to decorate the graves of soldiers who had died in the Civil War with flowers.

For many years, I have used this day to celebrate and remember my West Point 1989 classmates who are no longer with us. They all left us too soon.

This Memorial Day weekend, if you know a parent, spouse, child, or sibling of someone who served and died, please reach out to them personally. Let them know you remember their sacrifice and that you care.

Here is the full list of my classmates who are no longer with us.

Be thou at peace.

Congratulations to Jonathan Watkins, MPA, FACHE, president of City of Hope Cancer Center Atlanta, on being named to the Becker's Healthcare 2024 “Black Healthcare Leaders to Know” list.

As the president of City Hope Cancer Center Atlanta, Watkins is responsible for managing the hospital's business operations and enhancing its brand visibility. He works closely with his leadership team to facilitate growth and achieve success in the market while prioritizing the safety and satisfaction of patients. Watkins is dedicated to fostering partnerships with the local Coweta County and Georgia communities, aiming to position the center as a valued business ally. Additionally, he collaborates with the national leadership of City of Hope to access advanced treatments, leading-edge technology, expert cancer care and a diverse range of clinical trials.

“Diverse leadership in health care fuels innovation, equity and better patient outcomes," shares Watkins. "It’s an honor to stand alongside remarkable individuals who are making a difference in our industry.”

Read more: https://lnkd.in/gZVCxvef

Last week I graduated from The University of Nebraska with two master's degrees: an MBA with a finance specialization, and a Master of Science in Business Analytics.

This was an incredibly rewarding experience. My roles in my 30+ year career have generally been highly technical. Finance and Analytics were both interesting fields that I knew would make me better as a technical and operations leader.

My experience at Nebraska College of Business was outstanding. When I first started looking at programs, I was primarily interested in curriculum, particularly in these areas of finance and analytics. Which program included the classes that I thought I would enjoy taking? Nebraska was the best choice for me easily, offering a great selection of classes and a dual degree program that allowed additional coursework in both areas of study that I was interested in.  It is also a tremendous value – having been ranked as high as #1 in the country for value among online MBA programs in recent years. I couldn’t agree more.

I’m very appreciative of the support I received (both generally and financially) by my employers: originally Ball Metalpack and then by acquisition Sonoco Products.  Both organizations have been incredibly supportive of continuing education.

The support from my family was awesome. This was a demanding journey that I was trying to navigate – with a wife and three young children at home, and a senior leadership role in my day job. For the last four years, I dedicated 4am – 6am every day + additional weekend hours as needed to my studies.

This entire experience was completed, start to finish, while I was in my 50’s. I was almost always the oldest student in my classes and often older than the professor. There were lots of opportunities to share professional experiences in these classes, and I like to think I brought many interesting ones to our discussions.

What next? Well, 50-something years old is not too old to go back to school, and not too old to keep working at my most important job, as Dad. Mallory and I will welcome our 4th child in the next few weeks, right before my 54th birthday!

If you’ve been kicking around the idea of going back to school: do it! It’s never too late to keep learning! I couldn’t be more excited about my path over the last few years.

 Finally – if you’re worried that my years with Nebraska might have changed my college football priorities – well, I always cheer for the Irish first on Saturday. But when they aren’t playing…. GBR!

column2: Today, we pause to remember the brave individuals who made the ultimate sacrifice for our freedom. We observe this day by honoring and expressing our utmost gratitude for these heroes. #MemorialDay

I am honored and humbled to be recognized with the 2024 Women in Technology Award by the Dallas Business Journal. This award symbolizes more than just personal achievement; it represents the ongoing journey to break the glass ceiling for women in technology.
The awards luncheon was an incredible experience, surrounded by talented and powerful women and allies. My daughter left the room inspired, reminding me how important it is for us to pave the path forward for future generations.
Thank you, Dallas Business Journal, BravoTECH and CDW for your continued support and recognition of the Women in Technology in Dallas community for 11 years. I look forward to seeing this tradition continue in the years to come.
Special thanks to Tracey Bentley,Lauren Mortara (Kerr), Amit Mohan, Joyce King, and Rupam Gupta for being there to cheer and support me. You made my day very special.

I share this award with:
1. My husband - Madhu Reddy, son- Nihal K., and daughter - Shreya Kotragouda, for their unwavering support and sacrifices.
2. My mentors and sponsors, Neal Stephen and Janice Withers, for their continued guidance and encouragement.
3. My amazing Wells Fargo Commercial Lending Technology team and colleagues, who have supported and inspired me along the way.

I am extremely proud to be part of the Wells Fargo family and our company's commitment to Diversity, Equity & Inclusion. Every day, I am inspired and blessed to work with amazing women leaders like Tracy M. Kerrins and Sarah Berwick, who motivate me to strive for excellence.

Lastly, Congratulations to my fellow honorees! Way to go ladies!
Anabella Acosta Dr. Sandra Blanke Veronica Bloodworth Karen Campbell Adrienne Guillory, MBA Cheryl Choy Ambika Dadwal Tera Davis Elyse D. Cynthia Dixon Seema Dwarakish Kelle Fontenot Ayotunde Gibbs Ashley Glover Wei Wei Jeang Kristen Jensen Vanathy Lakshmi Shalini Prasad Alka Siddiqui

Globalde ve Türkiye’de teknoloji ve dijitaldeki değişiklikleri izleyen değil, şekillendiren yeteneklerden biri olacağına ve etkisi yüksek işler yapacağına inanıyor musun?

Insider. Co-founder ve CEO’su Hande Cilingir liderliğinde, Türkiye ve globaldeki en iyi üniversitelerden üst düzey yeteneklerin kabul edileceği Insider Prodigy Academy eğitim programı başlıyor.

Hande şöyle diyor: “Insider Prodigy Academy’i kurmamızın en önemli sebeplerinden biri, ülkemizde ve dünyadaki olağanüstü genç yetenekleri keşfetmek, benzersiz eğitimler ve mentorluk fırsatları sunmak ve tecrübelerimizi en etkin şekilde aktararak gençleri teknoloji dünyasına kazandırmak. Aynı zamanda uzun vadede bu gençlerin ülkemizden çıkan teknoloji girişimlerinin sayısını artıracağına inanıyorum. Çünkü şirketler toplulukları, hatta ulusları dönüştürme gücüne sahip. Bu bizim en büyük mirasımız olacak.”

Aşağıdakiler ilgini çekiyorsa Insider Prodigy Academy'e katılmalısın!

📍 Başarılı teknoloji şirketlerinin seçkin liderlerinin eğitimlerine katılma fırsatı
📍 Teknoloji dünyasının ve şirketlerin gerçek zorluklarını simüle eden projelerde sorumluluk alma fırsatı
📍 Dünya’nın en büyük teknoloji şirketlerini fonlayan yatırımcılar, sektöre yön veren liderler ve teknoloji dünyasının geleceğini inşa edecek genç yeteneklerle network olanakları
📍 Kariyerinizi şekillendirmenizi sağlayacak mentorluk görüşmeleri

Insider Prodigy Academy’e seçilen üniversite 4. sınıf ve yeni mezun olmuş gençler 2 aylık yoğun bir eğitim programından geçecek. Programın finalistlerine Insider'da uzun vadeli kariyer imkanları sunulacak.

Insider Prodigy Academy Yaz dönemi için son başvuru tarihi 23 Haziran!

Başvuru için: https://bit.ly/4dUwS7q
column23: Hande Cilingir ve Dilek DAYINLARLI super bi proje, tebrikler. Network'um deki butun potansiyel "prodigy" ler icin müthiş bir fırsat.

Last Thursday, we participated in the 2nd edition of the Cámara de Servicios Corporativos de Alta Tecnología -CamSCAT- People & Corporate Culture Day to share what Procter & Gamble Costa Rica is doing to foster inclusivity and enhance accessibility in the workplace. During the session, we presented our strategies to promote accessibility to more than 200 people representing over 50 affiliated companies.

According to the World Health Organization (WHO), approximately 1.3 billion people worldwide have a disability, representing 16% of the world’s population. People with disabilities encounter numerous barriers across society, including physical, communication, legal, economic, and social barriers, among others. At P&G, we are committed to creating a more inclusive world for everyone, which includes people with visible and invisible disabilities.

#PGEmployee #EqualityAndInclusion #DisabilityConfidence

Thanks so much to Marty Sheetz for organizing the #CarryTheLoad 5K challenge at Delta Dental Ins.

As a wife of a firefighter/paramedic, it means a lot to my family to honor the First Responders!  I’m often reminded of how fragile life is, and how blessed we are for the brave first responders who selflessly risk their lives to save ours.

But what we don’t talk about enough are the lives they couldn’t save, and the load they still carry wishing they could’ve done more.

Mental health awareness is needed more than ever with a suicide rate at an all time high for our firefighters.

While we honor our fallen brothers and sisters, let’s also support those still with us carrying the load.

#LifeatDDins #MentalHealth #Firefighters #FirstResponders #MemorialDay

Mary Callahan Erdoes, 56, leads JPMorgan Chase's $5 trillion wealth and asset management division and has a net worth of $300 million. Joining the firm in 1996, she has become the third-largest individual shareholder. Raised in Illinois, she was the only female math major in her Georgetown class and holds an M.B.A. from Harvard. Promoted to CEO of JPMorgan’s asset and wealth management in 2009, she has significantly grown the business. Erdoes is a board member of various organizations and is considered a potential successor to CEO Jamie Dimon.

column2:
🌟 LEADERSHIP MEMBER HIGHLIGHT 🌟

Qing Wang, Ph.D., PMP - Chair of IFT Food Microbiology Division

We are thrilled to spotlight Dr. Qing Wang, the Chair of the IFT Food Microbiology Division (FMD). An IFT member since 2010, Dr. Wang has been a vital part of the FMD since 2018, serving in various leadership roles.

Dr. Wang holds an MS in Food Safety from the University of Georgia and a Ph.D. in Food Microbiology from the University of Delaware. She began her professional journey at Sealed Air in 2016 as a Senior Microbiologist, where she led global projects and delivered specialized food safety training and consultancy. Transitioning to Solvay USA Inc. in 2021, and later Syensqo, she continues her microbiology background and expertise in developing biological formulations for agriculture, and driving innovation in the development of new 24-hour surface disinfectant technologies.

Dr. Wang's exceptional contributions have earned her the IFT Emerging Leader Award (2019) and Outstanding Volunteer Award (2021). She also serves as a judge for the IFT Bernard L. Oser Food Ingredient Safety Award and the IFT FMD Graduate Oral Competition. With her expertise and passion, Dr. Wang is committed to taking the FMD to new levels, and we are excited to be part of it.

column2:
Zions Bank and World Trade Center Utah (WTC Utah) Crossroads of the World truly put Utah on the map as they brought some of the worlds most influential leaders

A few Highlights

⭐️Former President George W. Bush was wonderfully engaging and personable. His humor had the crowd roaring and should be a stand up comedian, however his humor was interspersed with truly insightful and deeply meaningful (sometimes emotional) discussions on the hardships and care he has had for not only for the people of our nation, but all people — the women and children harmed as we left Afghanistan, the challenges for those impacted by our border challenges with Mexico, and the anger experienced on 9/11. Making me realize just how much broader our perspectives need to be.

⭐️ Mexico’s former President, Vicente. Fox discussing the opportunity for nearshore resourcing — so true, and I am working with companies in Utah that are building strong workforces based in Mexico and see how much we could expand in this arena.

⭐️ Former Prime Minister of Canada Stephen Harper was insightful on trade economics, and not onboard with any of the current proposed Utah National Hockey League (NHL) team names. (I tend to agree and truly hope “Yeti” does not stick!)

⭐️ Recognition of the incredible impact Scott Anderson has made to our state presented by our current Governor Spencer Cox along with prior Governors Gary Herbert, Jon Huntsman and Michael Leavitt

⭐️ Meeting with Derek Kitchen, prior State Senator and current Sr. VP & Deputy Director Congressional on the work happening within Export-Import Bank of the United States and FireFly Automatix, Inc.

⭐️ UVU President Astrid S. Tuminez interview with Richard Haass created awareness of the sensitivity of our global relations, the risks, and our role in becoming  informed. Having a marine son stationed in Okinawa these conversations become all too real, and his direct calls to action were welcomed (I did leave having bought 2 of his books.) 😂

⭐️Listening to Macky Sall reminded me of my time spent in Senegal  🇸🇳 in 2016 and saw first hand the impact of small investments being turned into massive change across the country. My time there was the foundation of the work I am now doing at Tech-Moms .

⭐️Wrapping up with Bear Grylls hyping us up and helping us face failure & fear with fire 🔥

Utah truly has placed themselves at the forefront of global engagement enabling future growth. We are all changing the world in our own way, and left informed and inspired.  Well done.

#utah #worldtradecenter #zionsbank #global #worldstage Zions Bancorporation

I had the privilege to participate in the first ever event between ALPFA New York and Bank of America Employee Resource Group HOLA NY titled: “Breaking Into Tech.” The event was hosted by Bank of America in New York City.

This event featured a panel of Latino technology executives who shared their experiences and expertise in the ever-changing tech landscape with ALPFA members from the Tri-State area.

The panel was moderated by Johanna Cordisco, MBA & featured fellow executives Erika Bustos & Piedad Burnside.  They did an excellent job and as usual, really brought their entire authentic selves to the event.

I want to recognize Damian Rivera, CEO of ALPFA for taking time out to be there in person as well as HOLA/ALPFA officers Luis Gasca, Daniel Roque, Angela M. Rucks, Michelle Cisneros, Benjamin Rene Garcia and Jaqueline Ramos.

Damian Rivera & Benjamin Rene Garcia, I will hound you both at every event until I get that ALPFA Inc - Association of Latino Professionals For America pin!

For all the attendees who we connected with after the panel, let's see some comments!  You all did you did a great job as well.  Without you, there is no event.

Thank You.

column2:
Well, that was fast! Just when I finally land my dream job at SAP the company announces a global restructuring. So, sadly, this week will be my last with SAP.

But, by any measure, I’ve had a great run during my almost 18 year tenure.  I’m so grateful to SAP for all of the professional opportunities I’ve had over the years, to the SAP customers I’ve been privileged to interact with and learn from, and to all of the incredible leaders and amazing colleagues I’ve had the opportunity to work with – past and present – so many of whom have become good friends.

Too many people to thank and acknowledge but a few I’d like to highlight to whom I’m especially grateful:

Al Kenney for 20+ years of friendship and for being my bridge to SAP. Peter T. Brandt for bringing me in to SAP and for helping me get started on this journey. Joerg Koesters for wearing every hat possible with me for the last 17+ years – coach, collaborator, manager, peer, advocate, co-conspirator and, most of all, great friend. Franz Josef Schoppengerd for your early mentorship, years of industry collaboration, continued friendship, and more than a few memorable meals along the way. Ram Jambunathan for your years of mentorship and inspiration, along with Alexa Gorman, Paul White, Max Kahn, Lior Weizman and the entire SAP.iO team for helping to contribute so much amazing innovation opportunity to Consumer Industries. Jeffrey Harvey for your relentless optimism and can-do spirit through thick and thin. And, finally, E.J. Kenney, Matt Laukaitis, and Lori Mitchell-Keller for your leadership, example, coaching and advocacy. I would not have had the career I’ve had at SAP without your encouragement, support and sponsorship.

Wishing all of my SAP colleagues all the best for continued success going forward.  As for me, I don’t yet know what's next but I’m excited to find out. For now, I plan to take a little time off to recharge and reassess and then looking forward to seeing what the future holds!
column23: Congrats on a great run Mark!  Best of luck on your next adventure!!!

column2:
I remember how nervous I felt a year ago when launching NEXT 🫣

Absolutely crazy that we’ve welcomed 300 members in the past year, selected from over 2,000 applicants 🤯

NEXT Careers members are all figuring something out – landing a new role, founding vs joining, building a fractional portfolio, if they should leave their current role, or some other transition moment.

Creating a space for entrepreneurial people to be authentic and vulnerable allows us to accelerate each other’s decision-making by tapping into our collective experiences and network.

This spirit of generosity is how we’ve been able to grow in such a high-quality way: almost half of the most recent cohort was referred by a program alum or a speaker.

I’m so grateful to truly hundreds of people who have helped build NEXT. From the amazing speakers who led over 100 live events, dozens of VC firms recruiting for their portco’s, supporters who have referred their most talented friends to join as well as the members co-creating this experience alongside me.

Really proud of the impact NEXT has had on the careers of hundreds of the most talented people I’ve ever met.

We’ve just opened up applications for our fourth cohort kicking off in a month and I’m so excited to meet our incoming crew 🤗

More info here: https://www.nextcareers.co

#jobsearch #hiring #startups

Today I hand over the P&G CIO responsibilities to Seth Cohen. I look forward to watching from afar to see how Seth and the team continue to take P&G’s digital capabilities to new heights.

I will finish an exciting and fulfilling journey with Procter & Gamble at the end of June, retiring from a career in IT which I started 39 years ago as Analyst Programmer.

Many people asked me what I am “really” going to do next. I will still stay connected to the world of technology, however my main objective for the next chapter is to dedicate time to my family and myself.

I have many memories to take with me, but the ones I will treasure the most are related to the people I worked with. I appreciate they shared the same passion for technology that drives business outcomes, and I am grateful for their dedication, hard work, and commitment to excellence.

Above all, I am thankful for everything I learned from them, for the lessons I was taught and for the perspective I was given. I wish everybody the same opportunity to learn and have fun as I had – and more.

Roger, Over and Out,

Vittorio
column23: Congratulations Vittorio Cretella! You are leaving behind such a footprint and I am lucky to have worked with and learnt from you.

column2:
Career Chapter Update:


In a previous post, I shared an image of an arrow on a tree I took while out hiking with my family that deeply resonated with me. It symbolized guidance and forward momentum in both my personal and professional life. The arrow reminded me of the beauty in growth and change, encouraging us to step out of our comfort zones, take the path less traveled, and trust the journey.

I'm thrilled to announce the next chapter in my professional journey as I join Wells Fargo as a Technology Executive in the Identity Access Management space!

My decision to join Wells Fargo reflects their iconic logo – the stagecoach journeying towards the new frontier of the West. This symbolizes new beginnings and endless possibilities for me. This imagery serendipitously aligns with my own journey towards growth and new horizons, acting as a declaration of growth inspired by my recent reflections.

Thank you again to everyone who has supported me along the way. Here’s to the journey ahead, to the paths we choose, and to the arrows and stagecoaches that guide us.

Last week while visiting our Hawaii market, I visited Lahaina and the burn zone. We met with several community partners including Roots Reborn, Hawaiian Community Assets, Nā Kia'i O Maui, Habitat for Humanity Maui, Na Hale O Maui and many others. I can share that seeing the devastation firsthand, and hearing about the impact, the resilience of the individuals, and the communities affected, was a profound experience. It reinforced the importance of being present and understanding the challenges the community faces.

I am incredibly proud of our community health team in Hawaii and their dedication to working alongside our communities to develop meaningful, impactful, and culturally relevant solutions focused on health and resilience. A special thank you to David Tumilowicz, Lisa Kimura and Vivian Pham, MA, PMP for their unwavering support and commitment to our communities. Together, we are leading efforts to rebuild and create lasting positive change through innovative, scalable, and impactful programs.

#KPProud #MauiStrong Edmund Chan MHA, RD, FACHE

Happy News 😁: I’ve joined Bilt Rewards as GM of Consumer Banking. I will manage the Bilt Credit Card program and broader roadmap of category changing launches (…stay tuned!). My observations 2 weeks in is that Bilt has the vision, momentum, and skill to become a household brand. The momentum is *very real*.

Now that I am here, it’s easy to say that the dots connected - even if it didn't always feel like they would as I searched. My time at Fannie Mae, American Express Citibank and HMBradly produced experiences that are uniquely relevant to Bilt - a four sided real estate, rewards, travel, and financial service platform. I’m thankful for those experiences.

Sometimes searches are like Goldilocks - keep looking until you find somewhere that feels exactly right 🥣.

I enter this new experience with gratitude for the many mentors, friends, and colleagues who helped guide me along the way.

October will be here before we know it, bringing colder weather and one of my favorite Microsoft initiatives—the annual Employee Giving Campaign. My recent tradition has been to donate a South OC Cars and Coffee experience to the Microsoft Online Auction, and of course, I always tag along.

South OC Cars and Coffee is California's largest weekly car meet, featuring hundreds of hypercars, supercars, exotics, classics, and more. This year, one of the winning bidders was Steve Kaiser, and we had a great time checking out all the amazing cars while supporting UNICEF, IRC, United Way of King County, and National 4-H Council. Thank you for giving and for joining me, Steve!

#GiveBack #MicrosoftLife

My time at Fannie Mae, American Express Citibank and HMBradly produced experiences that are uniquely relevant to Bilt - a four sided real estate, rewards, travel, and financial service platform. I’m thankful for those experiences.

Sometimes searches are like Goldilocks - keep looking until you find somewhere that feels exactly right 🥣.

I enter this new experience with gratitude for the many mentors, friends, and colleagues who helped guide me along the way.

Thank you, friends - I'll pay it forward ❤️: Alice Colarusso Rosa Sabater Jon Rosner Nicole Treiman Tanuj Suri Michael Krafft Lauren Meagher Megan Lyons Jason Rudman Joanna Lambert David Rabkin Rosa Alfonso-McGoldrick Becca Zoller Stone Isa Miró Jennie Platt Guillaume Bouvard Viviane Sabat Toby Osofsky Baer Tatyana Zlotsky Chris Cracchiolo Jenny Shum Sabrina Sodja Kramer Abbe Smith Lauren Batcheck Matt Mathieson Jodi Zamore Caryn Bonner Neha Kumar Janvi Jhaveri Farina Situmorang Agaja Reddy Alexandra M. column2:
Before the month of May comes to a close, I want to share the story of my husband Ed.  His last 16 months of life did not come close to defining his immeasurable impact on the lives of so many but he fought everyday with every inch of his body, mind, soul and heart.  He fought past boundaries and limits he shared with me & long after what he defined as his dignity- all to spend every moment he could  with our girls and I.
Ed, like many glioblastoma patients was a picture of health. He exercised, relentlessly, scrutinized everything he ate. He was committed to a vegan diet. He pushed himself beyond his potential every single day of his life. That’s who Ed was. That is Ed’s legacy.
 In April 2022 Ed was diagnosed with a glioblastoma, but not just your average glioblastoma, his tumor was a diffuse midline glioma uncommon for someone his age. It was also unmethylated and had a lethal type of mutation- all things that excluded him from most if not all clinical trials.  He had his first surgery 4 days after his diagnosis on April 6. He woke up and recovered extremely well. Two weeks later on May 4 he started six weeks of radiation and chemo and we traveled to the city every five days a week for 6 weeks.  Ed had MRIs every 1-2 months depending on the findings. During that time, our family lived one moment at a time surviving MRI to MRI. It continued to start the doctors with his progress, with his determination and positivity. The doctors would always remark that he never  “matched” his imaging. However, in October 2022, just 6 months later, MRI showed a small suspicious spot with hydrocephalus, (fluid accumulating in his ventricles). He had a second brain surgery for the insertion of a VP shunt and a biopsy. He woke up with weakness to his right side, but after a couple of weeks was pretty much back to baseline and the biopsy showed good news -the number of active growing cells was low.  Until in March, he started having some back pain.  The cancer had spread to the membranes around his spinal cord- he was given 3-6 months to live.  Then he contracted shingles in his right eye and scalp.  Some of you may have seen the PSA he did in the hospital urging people to get their shingles vaccine.
On April 20th we made the decision to start hospice. When he was in hospice where we almost took him off because he was doing so well:  lifting weights & he signed up for the New York City marathon.  Our girls and I had the honor and privilege to love and care for our Ed until his last breath.  We never left his side as we walked him home.
I will never forget the conversations we had during those countless hours in waiting rooms.  He wanted to make things better for patients like him and families like ours.
So now I run and post for Ed.  I will be running the NYC marathon in November fundraising for National Brain Tumor Society
Please join me in spreading awareness and supporting this organization.
#GrayMay

Cheers to the 2024 High School Grads just starting to make their own way! 🎉🎓
Life is busy, messy, stressful, nonstop, a constant puzzle of fitting in the moments of time to be everything to everyone, playing different roles in the many facets that life brings.  My closest friends get glimpses of our blessed #WaughFamilyLife on other social networks, but today I find it fitting to celebrate with this community, on our oldest son Preston's, high school graduation! 🎓 It was truly a blessing to see and reminded me of why this life of craziness is so worth it.  This kid is brilliant, bright, funny, kind, strong, fearless and makes us so proud.  Our family is as close as family can be, so it's not surprising that he has chosen to follow his parent's footsteps in attending CMU in the Fall pursuing a Computer Science degree.  Fire Up Chips!  There will be no limit to his success and he will have our unconditional love and support through all of what life throws his way.  Cheers to all the grads this year as they pursue their futures and ultimately make the world a better place.  And cheers to those shaping the lives of youth, it is the best feeling in the world when you see them succeed! 🌎❤️

Gratitude Post:

As I marked the completion of my two-year Cone Health administrative fellowship last Friday, I wanted to take a moment to express my deepest gratitude to everyone who has supported me on this journey.

Over the past two years, I have had the opportunity to work alongside an incredible team, learn from experienced mentors, and take on new responsibilities that have pushed me out of my comfort zone.

But it's not just the skills and knowledge that I've gained that I'm grateful for. It's the people who have made this experience so special. To my colleagues, who have become like a second family to me, thank you for your kindness, guidance, and encouragement. To my mentors, who have taught me so much and believed in me even when I didn't believe in myself, thank you for your wisdom and support. And to ELT, who have given me the freedom to grow and take on new challenges, thank you for your trust and confidence.

This fellowship has been an incredible opportunity for me to develop my skills, build my confidence, and prepare for my next chapter. I am forever grateful for the experience.

To anyone who is considering applying for a fellowship or similar program, I highly recommend it! The growth, learning, and connections you'll make will be invaluable.

#administrativefellowship #gratitude #professionaldevelopment #careergrowth

Recognize BIG moments!

At one of my son’s recent high school graduation, I was inspired hearing the wonderful ambitions so many young men and women are pursuing.

If I had known then what I know now, here are a few things I would tell new graduates:

1-The best opportunities for you may be far from home; pursue them now before other family and life demands grow in complexity.

2-Stay in contact with your good high school friends over the many years ahead; long friendships can be among the richest and they will eventually need you, and you them.

3-It sounds like everyone has a plan and their life is all perfectly mapped out while you are left behind trying to figure things out. They don’t. Move forward and make each achievement a building block for the next one.

4-If there was a special someone you always wanted to date in high school but didn’t, ask them out now. You’re out of high school and nobody cares anymore.

5-Your parents are suddenly much smarter now than they have been the past four years you were in high school. Ask for their advice and actually listen to it.

6-If you stay in shape, you’ll never have to get back into shape.

7-The best employers look for talent, then passion, and then personality. Develop those, and you will always be in demand.

8-The decisions you now make over the next four years of your life will determine much of what the rest of your life looks like. Shoot for the stars and don’t settle for subpar.

9-If you didn’t like the “box” that you were in or known for during high school, change it now. You write your present and future however you want it.

10-Thank your teachers and coaches every time you see them from now on. Decades from now you will still be quoting them and doing those same drills they had you do with your children’s teams that you coach!

The future is bright for all 2024 graduates and here’s to wishing you the very best of success!!

#graduation #advice

I am writing in memory of my wife, Karla Johnson, who left us on May 31, 2024, at the age of 54. Karla was an incredible wife and mother to our two sons, Collin Johnson and Connor Johnson. During our 32 years of marriage, I witnessed her love and generosity touch everyone she met.

Karla devoted her life to helping others and had a particular passion for pets, especially German Shepherds. Her commitment to education and pet shelters was a testament to her generous spirit. Karla was not only the family planner and holiday host but also a loving sister and daughter who brought joy and love to every moment.

Many have asked about how to honor her memory. In lieu of flowers, Karla would have preferred donations to her scholarship fund. This non-profit ensures that 100% of the contributions go directly to deserving scholarship recipients.
https://lnkd.in/gWSggxqN

If you prefer to send flowers:
Longview Flower Shop
https://lnkd.in/gzUgnpFn
903-758-7541

Address for the flowers:
Rader Funeral Home / Karla Johnson
1617 Judson Rd, Longview, TX 75601

We are holding a private family-only ceremony on June 07.

Thank you for your thoughts and support during this time.

Thank you,
Clay Johnson

🎉 Officially Opened! 🎉 We are thrilled to announce that Pinnacle Financial Partners Arlington office has opened its doors! Congratulations Rohita Choudhary & the entire team for their hard work and dedication in bringing this beautiful office to life. We invite all clients and community members to stop by and experience our exceptional services firsthand! #pnfp #growing #NCR #soft_opening

What an amazing journey with an even more exciting next chapter. It continues to be an absolute blast partnering with Manish Bhatt, Rahim Rajpar, Sanjay Mehra and Mario Arenas as we announce the acquisition by Simplicity Group and the rollout of the LifeLink™ platform.

A huge thank you to everyone who backed us, believed in us, challenged us, but always encouraged us to set and achieve lofty goals!

Today I hand over the P&G CIO responsibilities to Seth Cohen. I look forward to watching from afar to see how Seth and the team continue to take P&G’s digital capabilities to new heights.

I will finish an exciting and fulfilling journey with Procter & Gamble at the end of June, retiring from a career in IT which I started 39 years ago as Analyst Programmer.

Many people asked me what I am “really” going to do next. I will still stay connected to the world of technology, however my main objective for the next chapter is to dedicate time to my family and myself.

I have many memories to take with me, but the ones I will treasure the most are related to the people I worked with. I appreciate they shared the same passion for technology that drives business outcomes, and I am grateful for their dedication, hard work, and commitment to excellence.

Above all, I am thankful for everything I learned from them, for the lessons I was taught and for the perspective I was given. I wish everybody the same opportunity to learn and have fun as I had – and more.

Roger, Over and Out,

Vittorio

Wow, I’m feeling all the feels as I celebrate my six year Delta-versary at Delta Dental Ins.! I’m grateful for all the opportunities this company has given me, including my "Boss Man," Kurt Schroeder, giving me the support, runway and resources to build the team of my dreams! I’m appreciative of the #trust the company has put into me and my team to guide it through some of the most exciting and challenging times in its history – from transforming to a #healthcare company and leader in oral health, to navigating COVID and return to office, to protecting and promoting our reputation around critical issues. I’m energized by working for a #purpose-driven, #purpose-led organization where everything we do is in service of increasing access to quality care for all, because everyone deserves to smile and live a healthy, dignified life. And to the team who made this all possible – those who are still on team DD and those who have gone on to grow their careers elsewhere – I will forever be grateful to you for what we built together. We’ve come a long way in the past six years and have so much to be proud of, and none of it would have been possible without you.

Overall, I just feel really lucky to be here🥹 Here’s to many more! 💚💚💚

I wish everyone a Happy Pride Month.  At this time in our history it is as important as ever for employers to recognize that organizational diversity leads to more informed decision making, a cohesive workforce  and better economic outcomes.

As we celebrate Pride Month I encourage you to educate and bring along those who oppose the tenants of this month long celebration; inclusion, acceptance, joy, belonging, diversity.  These projectors of supposed 'virtue', who exist in most organizations and societies and who we all unfortunately have contact with, are the creators of exclusionary constructs that want to control you, maintain power and exert self-righteous mores rather than partner, grow and develop you as an individual.  They exist to the detriment of social, corporate and organizational cohesion.  Projected virtue in this sense is merely the marriage of caution and hypocrisy.  Speak openly about this hypocrisy to reveal to them and the world that  diversity is the reality of the human condition, even when they don't want to see it.  We are more successful as a species and a society when the full rainbow is seen!

Be Vocal

Be Visible

Be Yourself

column2:
"At the World Championships in Budapest in June, USA’s Anita Alvarez sank to the bottom of the pool.

Looking across the deck, then noticing she was under way too long, her coach, Andrea Fuentes immediately dove in after her fully clothed, pulling her to safety. Anita was unconscious and didn’t have the capacity to kick, paddle, or help herself in any way.

If Andrea had not have noticed, she would have drown.

But she knew Anita.
She looked for her, quickly noticed she was under too long, (nore than normal)
then dove in without thinking twice.

This has resonated with me….

When you are under too long, who are the people that will look for you, notice you aren't surfacing, and dive in to pull you to the surface when you lose your strength to swim in life?

Who are the people that would do that for you?

And can someone count on you to be that person that would go looking and notice when they are under too long, diving in to support them when they are all out of fight and fuel to swim in these turbulent waters we call life? "

Das ist die "Secret Sauce" hinter heyMia: 🤫

Vor gut einem Jahr war heyMia nur eine Idee. Heute haben wir eine Recruiting-Plattform mit fast 4.000 Talenten und über 200 Kunden. Wie haben wir das so schnell geschafft?

➡️ Unsere “Secret Sauce”: Low-Code Tools! 🧙

Von Anfang an haben Lukas Wohlgemuth und ich auf Low-Code Tools gesetzt, um technologisch sehr schnell voran zu kommen und einfach iterieren zu können.

Das sind die wichtigsten Tools, die sich bei uns bewährt haben: ⬇️

🧠 Airtable: Das Gehirn unseres Geschäfts! Damit managen wir unseren Talent-Pool und das CRM, und wir automatisieren Prozesse vom Onboarding bis zum Accounting. Mit Automation Scripts senden wir WhatsApp-Erinnerungen, berechnen Talent-Bewertungen, erstellen die Talent-Dossiers für Kunden etc.

🌐 Make: Oft benötigen wir neben Airtable noch andere Services/APIs. Mit Make verbinden wir Airtable unter Anderem mit Gmail, Google Drive, Zoom, WhatsApp und PDF-Tools. So können wir komplexe Prozesse abbilden.

💻 Webflow: Unser Webseiten-Wizard. Die erste Version haben wir mit einem angepassten Template (schnell & günstig!) gebaut, inzwischen haben wir unser eigenes Design entwickelt und bald gehen weitere Features auf heymia.ch live.

📱 Heyflow: Unser Tool zum Erstellen interaktiver, mobil optimierter Flows. Damit führen wir Talente und Kunden durch den Onboarding-Prozess und können die benötigten Informationen einfach abfragen.

Als “engineer at heart” bin ich beeindruckt, was dank Low-Code Tools heute möglich ist und wie schnell man damit technisch anspruchsvolle Produkte bauen kann. Und es macht richtig Spass mit diesen Tools zu arbeiten!

Ganz ohne Coding gehts natürlich schon nicht, auch wenn die Tools das gerne so versprechen. 😅 Mittlerweile ist unsere eigene Codebase ziemlich gewachsen. Aber hätten wir die Low-Code Tools nicht zur Verfügung gehabt, hätten wir viel mehr selber entwickeln müssen. Das wäre deutlich teurer gewesen und hätte ein Vielfaches der Zeit benötigt... 🐌

Ich kann Low-Code Tools zum Aufbau von neuen Startups/Produkten und zum Automatisieren von Prozessen also nur empfehlen. ✅

Was sind deine Erfahrungen mit Low-Code Tools?

_____
➡️ Möchtest du Low-Code Tools zukünftig in deinen Projekten oder deinem Unternehmen einsetzen, um die Effizienz zu steigern oder schnell neue digitale Produkte zu bauen? Let’s get in touch! 📥

#heyMia #recruiting #LowCode #Automation #Startup #Airtable

7 years ago, I decided to leave a corporate job and bought an RV campground.  You may be wondering...how did that go?  There are aspects I miss about my IT Career, such as a great network of professionals, the deployment of technology to solve business problems, and the challenges of working in a highly competitive environment.  And of course, there are difficulties in owning a campground.  While in the corporate world, there were times I had to clean up other people's crap, it can be more literal in an RV campground 🤢.  All said our business provides a service to guests that they love, I work alongside my family daily and run my own business how I see fit.  I have been very blessed by this adventure and I hope that you are in your own adventure no matter where you toil daily.

column2:
#PhysiciansAtHLTH

HLTH takes place every October in Vegas, and will take place this year on Oct 20th - 23rd.

For the last few years, I've created schedules and guides for physicians attending HLTH.  I'm a fan of these conferences because they focus on emerging healthcare technology, serve as a great way to network with physicians who have interesting non-clinical jobs, and feature a "who's who" speaker and panel lineup of leaders from hospitals, tech companies, and policy groups.

During prior conferences, physicians have been under-represented largely due to the cost of the event and because CME is not included.  However, both of these are going to change:
👨‍⚕️ HLTH has a new "Physicians at HLTH" track and they will be offering CME for some of the talks this year (https://lnkd.in/gJCDncND).
💲 Additionally, HLTH and Nisha Mehta, MD's Physician Side Gigs are going to be offering free admission for 200 physicians.  (more info here: https://lnkd.in/g_XaV_Yn and application here: https://lnkd.in/gKs7z5wZ)

So far, only a few speakers have been announced (Tom Mihaljevic, CEO of Cleveland Clinic and Joaquin Duato, CEO of Johnson & Johnson).  HLTH will also feature pitch competitions, American Medical Association's Physician Innovation Network events, StartUp Health company talks by physician founders, companies like Zus Health that are requesting physician feedback, and great parties 🎉.

Here is a link to a "A Physicians Guide to HLTH" I wrote about a past event (https://lnkd.in/dMzdb9X3).  I also included an the HLTH23 calendar, and I'll be making an HLTH24 calendar once more speakers and events are announced.

💻  My email away message has been a simple game-changer for me, and I'm offering you this idea in case it can be helpful for you too.

In startups, we agonize a lot over efficiency and scaling. But we do very little in our personal lives to become more efficient or scale our impact.

I used to drown in my inbox, occasionally putting up a vacation responder to assuage my guilt about taking a while to respond.

Then a 💡 went off. Why not keep the away message up ALL THE TIME? Most people want the same dozen or so things from me. And with a permanent away message I can triage these requests efficiently.

And with all that saved time, I have been able to write more blog posts to address some of the most common questions I get. Again, going from 1:1 to 1:many.

If you're struggling to keep your head above water in your inbox, I highly recommend giving a permanent away message a shot!

Today marks my 30-year anniversary with Frost a testament to our enduring #culture of integrity, caring, and excellence, and the power of building lasting relationships. I've learned along the way to pay attention to what matters most to our customers, understand the results of decisions, collaborate with others to deliver the best outcome, stay true to myself, and honor the legacies of others. The countless opportunities provided have showcased the abundant impact Frost makes on so many lives.

Our mission at Frost is to make all people’s lives better in the communities we serve, and I have personally been the recipient time and time again of that mission.

I am deeply thankful to everyone who has patiently guided and supported me on this remarkable journey. Your support has been invaluable, and I am forever grateful.

After a three-month hiatus, former Goldman Sachs executive Beth Hammack has landed her next gig as CEO and president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Cleveland.

Hammack's departure from Goldman in February was just the latest sign that the glass ceiling at the investment bank is still impenetrable. Despite its pledges to diversify its management ranks, Goldman has never had a female chair, CEO, president or CFO.

I wrote for Bloomberg Opinion at the time that we don’t know exactly why Hammack decided to leave, but we have plenty of clues. The company passed her over as CFO in 2021, instead moving Hammack into a position it claimed would eventually lead to a more senior role. (Spoiler alert: it didn’t.) And that’s despite being described by colleagues and industry insiders as a “unique talent who dedicated her life to the firm,” a “deep intellect” and “bound for higher office.”

She was said to have lacked “the swagger” of Goldman’s high-fliers and kept her “ties to a number of illustrious industry figures under close wrap," encapsulating the lose-lose position in which women at Hammack’s level frequently find themselves. Too little swagger and she’s considered “atypical” for Goldman; too much and research suggests she would risk being marked as overly ambitious.

The most striking and cringe-worthy anecdote I read about Hammack came from a former Goldman executive who told Bloomberg News in 2020: “She’s brilliant and she can explain the most complicated things in standard English. Once I thought of challenging her and asked if she could explain something in a Haiku.”

There’s a metaphor there — the impossible standards women at the top are held to, the extra mile they are asked to go, how little their time is valued. And no surprise, Hammack delivered the haiku first thing the next morning. So why did she leave? Maybe she just got tired jumping through all those hoops and never landing at the top.

So about six weeks ago, we decided to launch Joseph’s Challenge - No Limits. The intention was to raise £100k and the challenge is for Joseph, who has Down Syndrome, to try and run 10x10ks in 10 countries in 5 days at the end of August starting from a running base of zero.

If you want to support him please donate at
 https://gofund.me/5cc8d709 and if you want to follow Joseph’s progress, please follow him at https://lnkd.in/eUVjyueH.

The fundraising has gone so well that,including pledges, we are very nearly at our initial target of £100k and are now in the process of launching plans to create a social enterprise to support adults with special needs with training and employment opportunities in addition to hiring a disability sports officer. Massive thanks to all who have donated so far.

It’s been a big week this week with Joseph recovering from a knee injury, appearing on BBC and being a guest of the wonderful Chair of the FA, Debbie Hewitt in the Royal Box at Wembley receiving a signed Harry Kane shirt in recognition of his fundraising efforts so far. Joseph says he is more famous than his three sisters now….

We are also able to announce our first official partner, the wonderful Travelcounsellors, who are going to help manage the logistics of getting to 10 countries in 5 days with one or two jogs in between !!

We chose the title No Limits for this fundraising because when Joseph was born he spent three weeks in special care, didn’t walk until he was nearly three and everything we were told and read was about the limitations of a child with DS.

Lessons learned so far :

1) I am not very good on Instagram (I am managing Joseph’s Challenge account) - my youngest daughter tells me it’s sad to be following more people than follow you so please help me by following Joseph’s Challenge
2) I love the fact I am at an age where I don’t care about 1) !!!
3) Some people think it’s wrong to put someone like Joseph through a challenge like this - all I say to them is if you want to take him on at butterfly go for it !!!!
4) Most people are incredibly kind and go out of their way to support you when you put yourself out there
5) I am still afraid of failure and won’t relax until we have a social enterprise up and running
6) Joseph has taught us that if you go for 1% improvements and don’t cap your expectations or focus on a single target, you can really surprise yourself
7) Dont be afraid to ask so please donate !!!!
8) I have no idea how hashtags work but here goes ! #josephschallenge #travelcounsellors #nolimits #disabilitysports

Today is World Oceans Day, a United Nations observance that reminds us of the major role the oceans play in everyday life.

As part of our purpose to help protect the planet, Culligan has teamed with WILDCOAST, a coastal conservation organization based in California, to fund three solid waste retention systems that collect plastic and other waste before it enters the Pacific Ocean.

By the end of year one, Culligan expects to have prevented more than 40,000 pounds (about 18,150 kg) of plastic – the equivalent of three African elephants – from entering the ocean.
Find out more about the great work WILDCOAST do here: https://lnkd.in/gyNBV5Tk

#worldoceansday #sustainability #partnerships

I'm thrilled 😂 to share that I've successfully completed the 'Data Science and Machine Learning - Making Data Driven Decisions' program from the Institute for Data, Systems, and Society (IDSS) at MIT 🏫. My heartfelt gratitude 🙏 for the immense efforts ✍ put together by world-renowned MIT faculty, experienced, knowledgeable and passionate mentors 👨‍🏫 (Vinay Kumar Pallerla, Ishwor Bhusal, Amir Tavasoli, Anuj Saboo, Fred Premji), dedicated and empowering program managers (Jasper Gill, Shweta A.) and program team 👯. I will miss this challenging and fulfilling learning journey where I connected, collaborated and competed with the brightest minds 🧠. I highly recommend this program to all Data Science, AI/ML enthusiasts who are looking to dive deeper. Best wishes to all!

Developing a portfolio 📂 (https://lnkd.in/eN_vtVFE) of industry-relevant hands-on Data Science and Machine Learning projects using python and participating in Hackathon 🤼, applying all the learning 🤓 to increase the accuracy of the model, has been a great motivator and confidence booster 💪. I am really excited to put these skills to innovative work 💡 in real world applications and dive deeper 🏊‍♀️.

None of this would be possible without the unwavering support 😍 of my husband (Ritesh Shrivastava), kids 👨‍👩‍👧‍👦, extended family and friends! Celebrating my graduation from this program along with my daughter's (Prisha Shrivastava) graduation 👩‍🎓  from high school is an adorable memory to cherish forever :)

Proud to be a Brown graduate 👨‍🎓 and become a #Brunonian forever! I am thrilled and humbled to share that I graduated from Brown University with a master's in technology and leadership program this Memorial Day weekend!

As I proudly marched out of the iconic #VanWickle Gates, I reflected on the last one and a half years as an everlasting and extremely rewarding experience. I also reaffirmed the belief that when I am nervous and excited about something at the same time, I must do it!
Feeling accomplished and grateful to the awesome cohort, teachers, co-workers, family, friends, and Holman who supported me thru & thru on this journey successfully.

Leaving behind the all-nighters and looking forward to rolling on!!

"𝐄𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐧𝐞𝐮𝐞 𝐀𝐫𝐭 𝐝𝐞𝐫 𝐕𝐨𝐫𝐛𝐢𝐥𝐝𝐟𝐮𝐧𝐤𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧.“ 🏳️‍🌈

Mein Herz rast, ich bekomme Gänsehaut und beginne gleichzeitig zu schwitzen. Ich lese einen Artikel, der mit einem Zitat von mir endet – in einem der Top-3-Wirtschaftsmagazine Deutschlands. (Link im Kommentar)

Während es zahlreiche schwule Männer in meinem Umfeld gibt, kannte ich zu Beginn meines Outings nur eine einzige Frau, die sich als queer bezeichnete. Der Austausch mit anderen Frauen war mir damals fast unmöglich. Das möchte ich für andere ändern und eine Brücke bauen, um jenen, die vielleicht zögern oder sich unsicher fühlen, Mut zu machen.

In meinem professionellen Leben identifiziere ich mich nicht über meine Sexualität. Ich habe mich oft gefragt, warum ich beides mischen sollte. Dank des Austauschs mit beeindruckenden Persönlichkeiten, die sich als queer bezeichnen, weiß ich nun, warum ich beides mischen möchte.

Ein riesiger Shoutout an alle, die mich auf diesem Weg inspiriert haben: Til Klein 🏳️‍🌈 🇪🇺 Marc Funk Sabine Schoorl MBA 🏳️‍🌈Eva Kreienkamp Ulrich Dr. Köstlin Carmen Parra Moyano Mari Luukkainen

Lasst uns zusammenarbeiten, um eine inklusivere und vielfältigere Arbeitswelt zu schaffen. #Diversity #Inclusion #Pride
column11: Head of AI Capital Connect | Applied AI & ML

column2:
Working in New York allows me to regularly visit the original Bank of New York building, our founder’s Alexander Hamilton’s burial at Trinity Church, Wall Street, and the New York Stock Exchange. I am happy to be a part of this organization and its history. #lifeatBNYMellon

Given the 240-year history of the Bank of New York, we are fascinated by the perseverance that has defined our company.

Let this history inspire us to apply excellent engineering principles to all we do. Remember that quality is a habit more so than a performance. We work at it not occasionally but always, tenaciously, and resiliently.

Imbedding quality into what we do is a marathon, not a sprint.
Above all, one needs resilience. It also demands for patience. Accept the challenges, learn from our mistakes, and never give up on improving moving forward.

Best assets of BNY are its #people and its #resilience. Collaborating, we can protect BNY tradition and encourage originality and excellence in whatever we do.

To 240 more robust years to come! Happy Founders Day! #1784 #1869

#happyfoundersday #ham4ham #LifeatBNYMellon #HIStory #belonging #diversity #inclusion #waltonmansion #48wallstreet #thomasmellon #immigrant #charlestown #nevis

After working for start-ups for over 10 years, I decided to take a sabbatical in 2023.  During my time off I focused on recentering myself through mindfulness, exercise and healthy habits.  Thank you to my “person” and wife, Kelly James, for all your support.

At the 1 year mark, I started thinking about what I wanted to do next.  If I was going back to work, I wanted my experience to be enjoyable and fulfilling where I could help create something and make a difference.  I loved the sense of satisfaction of working with local and state governments and knew I wanted to stay in GovTech and with a smaller pre-IPO organization.

After a few months of research and discussions to identify my new adventure, I’m excited to share that I am starting a new position as Principal Customer Success Manager at Clariti.  Thank you Boaz S. Maor for the introduction to Clariti.  I am looking forward to working with Claytie Mistry (Moorman) and her Customer Experience Team.

A Beautiful June Graduation Day!!! 🎓🎓🎓

Congratulations to our 2024 cohort of incredible physician-leaders from all across the Houston Methodist system who graduated today from our Physician Leadership Development Program held in conjunction with Rice Business - Jones Graduate School of Business.

Over the past six months, they have had the invaluable opportunity to learn from both seasoned executives at Houston Methodist and distinguished professors at Rice University. This program was meticulously designed to equip them with the knowledge and skills necessary for effective leadership.

Today, our physician leaders showcased their group projects addressing current priorities within our system. It was wonderful to observe how they applied their program learnings to devise practical solutions that will significantly impact our entire healthcare system.

A special thanks to all of the capable executive sponsors of our team projects @Wayne Voss, Roberta Schwartz, Sarah N Pletcher, MD  MHCDS, Shawn Tittle, janet leatherwood, and the thoughtful leadership of Carla Braxton MD, MBA,FACS, FACHE. I very much appreciate the partnership of Michael L. Koenig and Zoran Perunovic who were instrumental in the design and development of this unique learning experience.

I can't wait to see how this group of leaders continues to grow, develop, and make Houston Methodist and the world a better place for ALL!

#leadingmedicine #physicianleadership #healthcare

It seems like today when you ask people how they are doing they always say “busy.” It’s as if “busy” in and of itself were the goal. Here’s what an AI search had to say about “busy” : Being busy doesn't always mean you're productive or making progress towards your goals. Being busy can be a state of constant motion without a clear purpose or direction. It can involve juggling multiple tasks without making significant headway in any one area. Being productive, on the other hand, is about making effective use of your time to generate results and move closer to your objectives.

Let’s get unbusy and get focused.

Keeping your word. Putting people before profits. Doing things the right way, even when it’s not the easy way. These values set Frost Bank apart and I live by them every day. If you’re ready for a bank where relationships really matter, give us a call.

After an incredible 35 years at EY, I am excited to let the LinkedIn world know that I will be retiring at the end of this week. There are too many acknowledgements to include all the great colleagues, clients, and friends I have worked with and learned from over the years in this post. However, I would like to take this moment to show my appreciation for Aaron Hipscher who left this earth way too soon and showed an incredible amount of confidence in me that I never would have found in myself. He took a chance on hiring me initially into the firm saying he knew this SUNY Binghamton kid from the Bronx had untapped potential. During the interview process, he insisted that I stop by the Arthur Young office after I had a 2nd interview with every other firm to check in with him. Aaron’s tremendous recruiting skills were evident when I landed in Vero Beach on September 11th, 1989, for 2 weeks of audit training. Thanks to him I was lucky enough to start my career with an amazing group of people that continue to be fantastic friends to this day.

During my 35 years at EY, there were times I got antsy and considered leaving. However, each time the power of mentoring helped redirect me to an interesting project or opportunity within EY where I was able to leverage the tremendous insight I had learned from auditing some of the most innovative derivative trading companies early in my career.  These experiences included two adventure filled overseas secondments to Tokyo, Japan.

Starting my next chapter, I am excited to share my experiences and insights with my Financial Statement Analysis students at Fordham University next semester. I am hoping I can sway some of them to enter the exciting world of Public Accounting. If that doesn’t work, I will just have to play Ben Affleck’s Accountant 2 in class when it is released!! In addition to teaching, I am excited to consider taking on some board positions to leverage my deep experience working with Japanese and US financial institutions as well as Private Equity clients throughout my career.

I feel so grateful for all the incredible experiences and relationships I’ve cultivated during my time at EY. I have worked with some of our largest Banking and Private Equity clients and so many talented and amazing people. Thank you to everyone I have worked with for all of your support over the years. I look forward to staying in touch as a new chapter in my journey begins!

We had a packed house yesterday at Houston Methodist where we hosted American College of Healthcare Executives members from across the country for a curated Innovation Open House.  My colleagues and I presented on some of our key strategic initiatives including responsible AI use, patient access redesign, and ambient intelligence in the operating room. We then toured the group around our Tech Hub and Virtual Operations Command Center.

Here are some of the key messages shared from our leadership team:

Jordan Dale, System Chief Medical Information Officer - Whether you realize it or not, you probably use AI every day from spell check on your phone to navigating with Google Maps and much more. AI tools are an important part of our innovation strategy at Houston Methodist to continue leading medicine, and we are committed to using AI safely and responsibly with an AI oversight framework that ensures human agency remains a top priority.

Tesha Montgomery, Senior Vice President for System Access - Our health system serves a massive population with the footprint of Houston being larger than some entire states in the USA. In surveying our patients, convenience rises to the forefront with a majority of patients stating that they would switch providers due to convenience factors alone. With our digital front door committee and patient access team, we are constantly working to improve all new technology that is patient facing and are proud to share that almost half of new patient appointments are successfully scheduled online.

Evan D. Collins, MD, MBA, Chief of Hand & Upper Extremity Center, and Rose McCullough, Director - Implementing ambient intelligence tools in our operating rooms over the past 18 months has significantly improved our OR scheduling and efficiency. In collaboration with our vendor, we have been able to make the technology work specifically for our needs at Houston Methodist.

#healthcareinnovation #healthcareAI #ambientintelligence #patientaccess

This month, we are celebrating the 10th anniversary of the Frost App! Here at Frost, we strive to provide the best experiences possible, both in person and on the go!

“I’m thrilled to celebrate the 10th anniversary of the Frost App. The original version was created through some of the best teamwork I have ever seen by a group of Frost Bankers who were obsessed with creating something our customers would love. We’ve never lost the spirit of that first team. Our current team works tirelessly to create simple and beautiful experiences that make people’s lives better. And we’ve never lost the personal touch. Our mobile team is immersed with our customers, constantly striving to understand how the app can get better and better. It’s this customer-driven innovation that’s helped us win the JD Power Award for Consumer Banking Satisfaction in Texas 15 times in a row,” said Jimmy Stead, Group Executive Vice President - Chief Consumer Banking Officer.

“We want to continually improve customer experience and to keep pace with evolving customer needs and expectations,” said Laura Miller, EVP Consumer Strategy & Digital.

Our top-rated banking app offers powerful features you’ll love to use, such as the ability to send money to friends, see all your accounts in one place and chat with a human for help. Get started and download the app today.

Last week, I had the pleasure of joining Noelle Eder and thousands of my colleagues at our tenth annual Cigna Technical Conference. Together, we discussed one of our greatest enablers – technology – and how we can harness it to deliver more value for those we serve today, and for those we will serve in the future.

While reflecting on our strategy, our accomplishments and our areas of opportunity, I shared some words of advice I think apply to us all.

Always look for bright spots rather than flat spots. As humans, we are wired to look for the flat spots when something goes wrong. But if we switch our mindset to seek out the bright spots, we can delve into what is going well, learn from it and apply it to achieve even better outcomes in the future. By continuing to learn and share in service of our mission there is nothing we can’t accomplish together.

To my #TeamCignaGroup Technology colleagues around the world, thank you for what you do each day, and for what lies ahead, to innovate solutions that deliver more personal, predictive, convenient and connected care for those we serve.

Put your insecurities away and get on with achieving your goals. Reflect and remind yourself that an accurate criticism is the most valuable feedback you can receive. Imagine how silly and unproductive it would be to respond to your ski instructor as if he were blaming you when he told you that you fell because you didn't shift your weight properly. It's no different if a supervisor points out a flaw in your work process. Fix it and move on.

#principleoftheday

column2:
I am glad to see that the recent Peterson Health Technology Institute (PHTI) report on virtual MSK care aligns with the broader body of evidence supporting the efficacy of virtual physical therapy. However, I am disappointed that several studies used to support the efficacy of “PT-guided” care do not mention the involvement of a physical therapist in the intervention. The American Physical Therapy Association (APTA) and every state practice act make it clear that one must be licensed to practice physical therapy to call their services physical therapy whether that care is delivered virtually or in-person. Grouping non-PT interventions under “PT-guided care” weakens a report that otherwise delivers an accurate assessment of the opportunity for virtual physical therapy to deliver value in MSK care.

Check out more of my perspective in a piece co-authored with Carolyn Bradner Jasik, MD:

BCH announces new Chief Information Officer

Boulder Community Health (BCH) is pleased to announce that Teresa Cole, currently Associate Vice President of Technology and Value Chain at BCH, has accepted a new role as Vice President/Chief Information Officer (CIO). She will assume the role of CIO on June 17 following outgoing CIO Michael Jefferies’ departure. Jefferies, who has served as BCH’s CIO since 2016, is moving to the Netherlands with his family to pursue a unique opportunity to live abroad. He has founded a Dutch business and plans to continue his work in health care in Europe.

As I take on new challenges and interests, I wanted to mention some of the people who have influenced me a lot and express my gratitude. I could not have asked for a better growing experience than that of the State Street Board who has been consistently ranked among the top 25 global boards. As I start serving on boards you will remain my North Star on how an effective board should operate. I would like to thank Dame Amelia Fawcett DBE, CVO Lead Director, Sean O'Sullivan Chair Tech & Ops Comm & Marie Chandoha Chair Risk Comm. Sean, I will forever treasure your support & guidance.

Thanks Ronald O'Hanley, for your support for diversity & inclusivity. #FearlessGirl continues to fearlessly inspire thousands everyday.

Steven Fay CPC Federal Reserve Bank Boston, you & your team were highly supportive & appreciative of my efforts, very grateful. Tough, when needed, but collaborative, you embody how effective regulators should operate, both ensuring the smooth functioning of the US Financial System, while challenging the industry to get better. Thanks Michael Bertulli, Ed Charlton, Linda Lue-Bezzat, Janele Cooper & Jeffrey Baglioni

To former colleagues,
Lou Maiuri, you rock. Never met an executive who can operate so effectively from board room to the mail room, from the “C” suite to the “Coding" suite & everything in between. To Andrew Kuritzkes what an unbeatable second act !!, as CRO for the nation’s CHIPS program your impact will last decades. Thank you Barbara Diette, Wynne Rumpeltin, Kris Wulteputte, Ajay Mathur, Mark Corteil, Jacqueline Angell, my risk comrade in arms

Thanks to my business partners over the years for keeping a risk mindset - Brian Franz, John Plansky, Antoine Shagoury, Sarah Berwick, Ram Puppala, Ann Fogarty, Adeel Saeed, Elizabeth Joyce, Andrew Zitney, Aman T., James Hardy, Jit Vekaria & Kishore Kottapalli.

As leaders we are only as good as our teams - leaders look tall because they are being carried by Giants. To my team of giants, I am so incredibly proud of all that we have achieved. You have punched way above your weight class & helped establish one of the best cyber/tech/3rd party/resilience/operational risk programs in the industry. column2:
I’ve met a few noteworthy people in my life, but none of them have had a significant impact on me (personally or professionally). That all changed yesterday.

While waiting in the lobby to see my eye doctor, a man walks in and greets the staff like they are family. He laughed with everyone, knew everyone’s names, shared jokes with them, and treated them like his own.

When I first looked his way, I knew I recognized him. It looked like Richard Davis, but I didn’t want to say anything. For those of you that don’t know Richard Davis, he was the CEO of U.S. Bank during the financial crisis and how he led the company through it truly inspired me.

At that time, all major banks were roiling because of the market crash and the failures of multiple financial institutions. As strong as U.S. Bank was, the company was not immune to feeling the impacts. Instead of cutting jobs like many other banks were doing at the time, he offered a different solution. Everyone will take a 5% pay cut and nobody loses their job. I was just a 20 hour teller at the time while I was going to school. I really didn’t have any sense of how significant that idea was until I looked back on it. Everyone gave a little bit so that we could all make it through the hard times together. That last word, together, is the key part.

Mr. Davis’ leadership and example has inspired me throughout my career. First and foremost he taught me that employees are not just numbers or financial burdens, they are the members of a work family and are the key to a successful business. Happy employees are more productive and ultimately produce better results. While at the helm of U.S. Bank, he truly believed in that philosophy and it permeated throughout every level of the organization.

Returning to my story from earlier, the office staff called him by name. “Hey Rich!” At that moment, I knew it was, indeed, Richard Davis. I greeted him by name, he quickly stood up and shook my hand, and we shared a conversation. I also knew I couldn’t pass up an opportunity to get a photo with him. Obviously I wasn’t dressed the best, but who likes to go to the doctor in work clothes?

It was an honor to meet you, Mr. Davis!

From Senior Prom to Senior (Young!) Citizens: A 53-Year Love Story

As we mark Loving Day today, June 12th, I am reminded of the enduring power of love and resilience. In November 1971, a few years after the landmark Loving v. Virginia decision, considered one of the most significant legal decisions of the civil rights era, a senior boy asked a junior girl on a date (my/our first date). We attended a concert by Motown’s one and only Temptations (the original singers, I might add!), which turned tempting parents on their heels. We were high school students at a Catholic school, and our decision to go on a date was met with significant backlash. The school administration and several parents expressed dissatisfaction, calling the school to voice their disapproval. Yet, amidst the uproar, my parents, originally from Alabama, and his parents, from Montana, stood by us.

Some civil rights history: In 1958, Richard Loving, a white man, and Mildred Loving, a Black woman, were married in Washington, D.C., where interracial marriage was legal. Upon their return to Virginia, they were arrested and charged with violating the state's anti-miscegenation laws, specifically the Racial Integrity Act of 1924. This law prohibited marriages between white and non-white individuals, reflecting the entrenched racial segregation of the time.
The Lovings—how fitting that their last name was Loving—were sentenced to one year in prison, with the sentence suspended on the condition that they leave Virginia for 25 years.

Unwilling to accept this injustice, they challenged the conviction, leading to a Supreme Court ruling on June 12, 1967. The Court unanimously declared Virginia's anti-miscegenation laws unconstitutional, stating that such laws violated the Equal Protection and Due Process Clauses of the Fourteenth Amendment. Chief Justice Earl Warren asserted, "The freedom to marry, or not marry, a person of another race resides with the individual and cannot be infringed by the State." Reflecting on this historic decision, it's sobering to consider how today's Supreme Court might view such a ruling.

Note: It wasn't until 2000 that Alabama officially removed its anti-miscegenation law from the books through a public referendum, underscoring the deep-rooted racism and resistance to interracial marriages even decades after the Loving decision.

Our journey from that first date in 1971 to celebrating our 45th wedding anniversary this summer is a testament to us and to the progress and challenges that remain in society. We have been together for almost 53 years, dating nearly eight years before getting married. We continue to witness the good, bad, and ugly societal attitudes toward #interracial and same-sex relationships.

We hope that by sharing our journey, we can educate and inspire others about the importance of love, equality, and the ongoing fight against #discrimination in the broader struggle for marriage equality for everyone.

I am pleased to announce that I have accepted a position of Presidential Innovation Fellow in Artificial Intelligence (AI) from the Office of the White House, as part of their National AI Talent Surge program.

My first day was today in Washington DC.

I am in the June 2024 cohort, and will be stationed at the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS) agency focusing on AI in healthcare - specifically AI Strategy.

This is a competitive appointment of thousands of applications nationally for only 11 positions, I am the sole AI PIF at CMS, and the 2nd ever in Minnesota's History.

The Presidential Innovation Fellows (PIF) program was established by the White House in 2012 to attract top innovators into government, capable of tackling issues at the convergence of technology, policy, and process.

The program is a partnership between the White House, the General Services Administration (GSA), and the Office of Management and Budget (OMB).

The AI Executive Order announced October 30, 2023 directly references Presidential Innovation Fellows as part of the AI Talent Surge.
