column2:
20 yr Workiversary

Thanks to the many friends, colleagues, and clients who congratulated me over the last week regarding my 20th anniversary with Frost Bank. It’s been a great ride, and I’ve no intentions of getting off any time soon.

Milestones are funny things though. I realized, for example, that I’ve now worked at one place longer than I lived in my hometown of Knippa! Or, that the city I moved to (MSA of ~ 1 million in 2004), having just been ranked the fastest growing MSA in the country for a staggering 12th consecutive year, is no longer a mid sized college town, but now a burgeoning internationally recognized City of 2.4 million - with all the perks and challenges that come with that kind of growth. Or that the company I joined would evolve into a top 50 bank in the US with nearly 200 branches and industry leading people and products (see #1 in customer satisfaction JD Power rankings,  or best mortgage lender in Texas by CNN).

And when I think back on the kid I was back then, I realize just how fortunate (blessed) I’ve been these past two decades to have people in my life who’ve gone out of their way to help mentor and guide me along the way. While too many to thank individually, there are a few I do have to call out specifically. Ronnie Miksch, Tim Crowley, Will Ingram, Keith Donahoe, John Schawe, John Greenwood, Ken Gates -  Your kindness, direction, and coaching (yes Ro, I’m talking to you) made me the banker I am today. I’ve still got lots to learn, but I owe each of you a great deal for your help along the way.

I want to close with the thought I shared with the team last Friday morning as we celebrated with some chicken minis (cause everyone loves those things!). And that is, I’m more optimistic today about the future here at Frost than I’ve ever been. It feels like Frost, and specifically the Austin team, is having our moment in the spotlight, as we hire up and grow across the region. I couldn’t be prouder of the people I get to do that with, and if you need a good bank to help you, or your company, give me a call, I genuinely would love to help.

Cheers y’all.

-david

For the past 21 years, I’ve had this 1960’s board game framed just outside my personal office Spanx. Every time I walk past it, it’s a reminder of how far we’ve come. ⁣
⁣
It came out 5 years before I was born. There are six career options for women; a ballerina, model, actress, flight attendant, nurse and teacher. At the time this board game came out, it was very progressive because women weren’t encouraged to work at all. THIS WAS NOT THAT LONG AGO!!! Let this reminder be what fuels you to dream big, take risks, be bold, disrupt industries, invent, redefine the conventional image and definition of success, and never let fear hold you back from trying new things or from becoming the best version of yourself. ⁣
⁣
Think of all the women who came before us that never got the chance. Every day I wake up with gratitude for more options, and deeply appreciate the women and men who came before me who spoke up, showed up, and pushed society to allow women to be deemed worthy enough to vote, worthy enough to get a business loan, and ultimately decide what they want to become. ⁣
⁣
#Gratitude #WomenEmpowerment⁣

I’m honored to share that I have been elected to HP’s Board of Directors!

Over the weekend, just before my appointment, I had the opportunity to visit the HP Garage – the birthplace of Silicon Valley! It’s where college friends Bill Hewlett and David Packard decided to start their very own company back in 1938 and went on to blaze a trail, sparking technologies that continue to shape the world today.

The HP Garage is an enduring symbol of innovation and entrepreneurship, two elements that underpin HP’s vision to create technology that makes life better for everyone, everywhere – every person, every organization, and every community around the globe. And I am thrilled and inspired to be part of this.

I’d like to express my sincere gratitude to the HP Board for entrusting me with this responsibility - I look forward to guiding HP into the future and contributing to its continued success.

For those who’ve asked…

Yes, it is the best Father’s Day gift I’ve ever gotten. But not for the reason you think.

As parents, Neil and I tell the kids they can be anything they want; that no dream is impossible. And that no one succeeds alone.

How extraordinary when you can show your kids that what you’re telling them is true.

I feel so grateful to have been part of this team, where everything worked because everyone worked together. From the lighting, sound, and scenic design, to the costumes, wigs and makeup; from the story, score and orchestrations, to the cast, crew and choreography. With an outstanding team of producers and a director who brought a brilliant vision and - with genius and generosity - let her team do its best work to bring that vision to life.

I feel humbled to have been in the company of our fellow nominees, each of whom illuminated the human experience through their art.

Thank you and congratulations to The Araca Group, Matthew Rego, Michael Rego, Hank Unger and Cristina V., to my friends Sue Gilad and Larry Rogowsky, to American Zoetrope, Angelina Jolie, all of our co-producers, the team at the Bernard B. Jacobs Theatre, our brilliant director Danya Taymor and the amazing cast, crew and creatives who take us, every night, to Tulsa, 1967.

I feel so grateful to my parents, who always let me be me; and my husband, Neil, who always catches me.

And to my wonderful kids, who fill me with wonder and remind me that anything’s possible:

Ignore the people who tell you, you shouldn’t. Tune out the voices that tell you, you couldn’t.
Embrace those who tell you, you should, could and will. And, as Kecia Lewis said last night:

Don’t. Give. Up.

Lea also joined some of our Swiss events throughout the years and always made sure to be giving back to the startup community. She is a real role model!

So, of course, when I first read about the AVA Women exit, I was really happy for her and her team, and then once I heard about the acquiring company declaring bankruptcy shortly afterwards, I was quite saddened at the thought of how this would affect them.

I'd been trying to get Lea on the podcast to talk about everything she's learned along the way for a while now, and it wasn't until startup days 2024 in Bern that I finally succeeded. It was touching, deeply personal and really eye-opening.

column2:
I am beyond excited to share that I have recently graduated from the MIT Executive MBA program MIT Sloan School of Management

It’s hard to believe it’s been 2 years since I started this journey, and I can still feel the excitement, inspiration and trepidation in taking on something seemingly monumental. Buckle up, they said.

I went all-in. I said Yes to every opportunity, I challenged myself, I got out of my comfort zone, I dug deep, I had big wins and and balancing setbacks, I persevered, I learned, and I transformed. 👩🏻‍🎓

I explored my strengths as a systems thinker and a sensemaker, I leaned into my passion for community development, I expanded my reach, I developed lifelong friendships, and I defined my mission to make impact through climate solutions. 🌱

I also learned that I might have missed my calling as a game show host.

The timing of this education was also magical. Being a student at MIT during the AI revolution was pretty special. AI will continue to transform our lives in ways that nobody fully understands yet, and we had a front seat for it. Seeing the transformation from a variety of perspectives and most importantly through intimate conversations with top leaders driving the vision, steering the evolution and adoption of the technology on a day-to-day basis and shaping the AI enabled world we all live in..  Definitely a highlight of this education. 👩🏻‍💻

With the pace of change in the world today, coupled with the speed of technological advancement and unprecedented geopolitical instability, polarization and climate change, leadership is needed more than ever, and thoughtful leadership makes all the difference.

I’m most encouraged, excited and hopeful about the work I’ve done to discover and develop my leadership signature, the uniqueness of my particular style, and for the safe environment in which I could take risks, test out some new ‘material’ and bring all of it to bear in activating my vision.

I couldn’t possibly be more grateful. For the opportunity to build a community with this incredible group of people, and for the unwavering support of my friends and family. It has been amazing to expand my tribe and chart a course with you all.

And you’re amazing if you read this far! Brevity is not my strong suit, but I’m working on it!

Aaaand that’s a wrap!  👩🏻‍🎓✅

Onward. 🌱🫶🌍

column2:
🌟 Exciting New Chapter Ahead! 🌟

After an incredible journey at Microsoft, I am announcing my departure from one of the most powerful, innovative, and talent-rich companies in the world. I feel truly blessed for my time here and have met so many incredible people who will remain friends for life. 🏆🥇

I have made the bold decision to leave my favorite workplace to strengthen and utilize my capabilities in transformational leadership, a passion close to my heart. I have said yes to one of Danish history’s most significant transformation cases at TDC Erhverv, where I will take on the role of Senior Vice President for Enterprise and join the Executive Board.

Starting July 1st at TDC Erhverv, my responsibility will be to accelerate the sales of end-to-end solutions and advanced services to enterprise and public customers. This initiative aims to solidify our market leadership as the only provider capable of delivering across all technologies.

There is a special reason I chose TDC Erhverv:
"TDC Erhverv is a strong and iconic brand that is on an exciting and ambitious transformation journey. My passion and strength lie in transforming organizations through modern change management, making a noticeable difference internally in the company culture and contributing to strengthening customers' digital journeys and business results. I look forward to contributing to strengthening our focus on spreading end-to-end value-based digital and AI solutions for the benefit of Danish society.”

I would like to thank Microsoft for the most developing years of my career. You are sending me out into the big world so much wiser and prepared for the challenges ahead. Thanks, from the bottom of my heart. ❤️

Thank you to the leadership, my team, my colleagues, and ALL our partners and friends in the ecosystem. You have ALL made the last 3.5 years incredible. #MemoriesForLife Together, we have built history. Thanks for everything ❤️ Thanks for all your support, partnership, and innovation.

See you all again one day 👌 And to all my new friends - see you soon. I’m so excited to meet you all…

Our life is a book consisting of many chapters. This is just one of them. 😘 Remember to enjoy every step you take... We don’t know how many we will take.

❤️ Thanks, AB ❤️

#NewBeginnings #TransformationalLeadership #Grateful #Microsoft #TDC #Nuuday

column2:
The best in the world are the most ok with being horrible first.

Check out Ed Sheeran’s first song:

I love this video because it shows that someone who is considered incredibly talented NOW was absolutely awful early.

He got good by practicing incredibly hard - not just because of natural abilities.

Most of the great joys in my life are on the other side of being horrible at them early. Being an entrepreneur. Writing online. Helping CEOs solve problems.

Question:

What are you resisting doing more of that you really enjoy - but that you are awful at today?

I bet you are not as bad as Ed Sheeran’s first song.

Get after it. I’m rooting for you.

column2: I was honored to attend this event last night and support my friend Sarah Brachle Wagner in her work to ensure that people have a decent place to live, with funds raised supporting work across six counties. Amazing to see the impact of the honorees!

20 yr Workiversary

Thanks to the many friends, colleagues, and clients who congratulated me over the last week regarding my 20th anniversary with Frost Bank. It’s been a great ride, and I’ve no intentions of getting off any time soon.

Milestones are funny things though. I realized, for example, that I’ve now worked at one place longer than I lived in my hometown of Knippa! Or, that the city I moved to (MSA of ~ 1 million in 2004), having just been ranked the fastest growing MSA in the country for a staggering 12th consecutive year, is no longer a mid sized college town, but now a burgeoning internationally recognized City of 2.4 million - with all the perks and challenges that come with that kind of growth. Or that the company I joined would evolve into a top 50 bank in the US with nearly 200 branches and industry leading people and products (see #1 in customer satisfaction JD Power rankings,  or best mortgage lender in Texas by CNN).

And when I think back on the kid I was back then, I realize just how fortunate (blessed) I’ve been these past two decades to have people in my life who’ve gone out of their way to help mentor and guide me along the way. While too many to thank individually, there are a few I do have to call out specifically. Ronnie Miksch, Tim Crowley, Will Ingram, Keith Donahoe, John Schawe, John Greenwood, Ken Gates -  Your kindness, direction, and coaching (yes Ro, I’m talking to you) made me the banker I am today. I’ve still got lots to learn, but I owe each of you a great deal for your help along the way.

I want to close with the thought I shared with the team last Friday morning as we celebrated with some chicken minis (cause everyone loves those things!). And that is, I’m more optimistic today about the future here at Frost than I’ve ever been. It feels like Frost, and specifically the Austin team, is having our moment in the spotlight, as we hire up and grow across the region. I couldn’t be prouder of the people I get to do that with, and if you need a good bank to help you, or your company, give me a call, I genuinely would love to help.

Cheers y’all.

-david

On June 19, 1865, two and a half years after the Emancipation Proclamation, enslaved people in Galveston, Texas, learned of their freedom. This day reminds us of the long journey toward equality and the work still ahead. Let's celebrate, educate, and continue striving for a just and inclusive society. #Juneteenth #FreedomDay #BlackHistory #Equality

column2:
I’m happy to announce that after what felt like the longest 7 months of my life, I’ve finally removed my green banner! I’ll have more on where I’m going next and the people who were instrumental in helping me get there a little later on.

For now, there are a couple of things at the very top of my mind as I start the next chapter of my career:

Without my support system, I wouldn’t have made it through the last half year. First and foremost, I want to thank my wife Erin Powell, who was my financial and emotional rock throughout the weeks and weeks and months and months of applications, cover letters, interviews and disappointment. She kept me together and kept our family’s collective heads above water, and I don’t know where I’d be right now without her. Someday, I’ll also tell my son how, as a toddler, he helped his dad through one of the most challenging periods of his life just by being a smiling and giggling source of joy, energy and motivation who served as a much-needed distraction from my situation. My family, friends and former colleagues have all been heavily involved in keeping me going. The messages of encouragement and support. The offers to help set up connections and conversations, or to even just take a look at my resumé and offer feedback or advice. The silver lining through all of this is that I have a lot of people in my corner, more than I ever even knew, who were willing to be my champion or a sympathetic ear. Words can’t adequately express my gratitude for the love and support I’ve received since day one when I was laid off and nearly every day since. I was down bad, and you all helped lift me up.

To my fellow green banners who are still hoping to get that call or email with a job offer attached to it, I want to let you know that I see you and support you. The job market is a cruel and miserable pit of despair right now. The ghosting, rejection and silence can all feel overwhelming at times. People can tell you there will be light at the end of the tunnel, and while there will be, it can be so hard to look beyond your current situation. It’s always easy to tell you not to take things personally, it’s just business, but few things impact your personal life more than your professional life. It’s okay to feel angry or frustrated or sad. All I can say is to keep going, believe in yourself and your talents and, most importantly, take the occasional day to yourself to do the things that you love with the people you love. Something will come along eventually. If ever there is a chance for me to help you the way so many others have helped me along the way, please reach out. Unemployment is a long and lonely road, no matter how many people you have in your corner, so don’t be afraid to ask for help when you need it. I believe in you.

TTFN

column2:
Glad to finally see Biden doing this. He can't out-Trump Trump on this front; just using all sticks with no carrots as immigration policy. I am all for clamping down on illegal immigration but we need to fix the legal immigration mess. Policy towards the spouses of citizens and legal immigrants has been outright cruel.

America is a land of immigrants and its economy totally depends on immigrants to keep growing. America has not had an employment problem for a long time. Its dependence on Filipino nurses is absolute, almost 35% of nurses in US are from Philippines. Its dependence on Indian American IT engineers is also fairly absolute. Same is true in agricultural sector where Mexican labor has become indispensable. 15% of the US population is foreign born. Close to 30% of the population has an immigration  connection.

While it stops illegal immigration, it needs to welcome much needed legal immigrants. With this announcement today, and the announcement of clamping down at border two weeks ago, President Biden has started to differentiate himself from DJT.

Let the voters have the final say in November.

If our purpose is why we exist, then our values are what we believe. I’m proud to be a member of the 10-person caring, inclusive and courageous team from around the Colgate-Palmolive world that helped reimagine and relaunch our Company’s values in May 2023:

❤️ We Are Caring
🤝 We Are Inclusive
🦁 We Are Courageous

These values can guide the actions we take as we work to advance our purpose to reimagine a healthier future for ALL.

I want to thank our Company’s Chairman, President and CEO Noel Wallace and our senior leaders for recognizing us by awarding The Chairman’s You Can Make a Difference Global Award.

In 2023 alone, more than 1,800 projects were nominated by 82 committees from around the CP world — with five ultimately selected for the YCMAD Global Award. Receiving this is humbling because I know how impactful and deserving the other projects are.

This week, we were recognized by our Board of Directors and CP’s senior leaders at a special gala dinner; received a stock grant and learned about what it means to be a stockholder at a special visit to the New York Stock Exchange; celebrated with a sail and dancing in New York Harbor; and so much more.

Shout-out to the Values Team based in London, Toronto, New York City, Basel and Johannesburg: Brad Watt, Viviana Moreno, Jenn Porter, Kevin Jordan-Deen, Stephanie Bereday, Vigla Clarke-Allison, Jean-Christian Heinzelmann, Priyan Pillay and Balunji Nkhwazi — and to all the 2023 Global Winners!

I feel immense pride for being recognized and seen not just by CP’s senior-most leaders and peers but also by my partner Matthew Kelleher, who was included as my special guest for the week’s festivities.

Thanks Matt for recognizing me too! 🥰🥰🥰

Congratulations and thanks to Mitali Chopra, my Global Corporate Communications teammate and YCMAD Program Global Employee Chair; our creative director and event MC Kevin Bender; and Melissa Covington in our CFO’s office, who were crucial to the success of this celebration week alongside a strong, driven team of 30 colleagues.

My hot take on the whole experience: change is inevitable and we can’t possibly do everything. But when we’re guided by our purpose and values, I believe we CAN do anything.

column2: June Gold Star of the Month is Bailey Madison Bancroft, also known as Maddie. She lost her father, Marine Captain Matthew Bancroft, when he was killed in action during a deployment to Pakistan in 2002. Maddie shares her experiences with the Folded Flag Foundation by saying, “I am profoundly grateful to the Folded Flag Foundation for the support that they have provided me with and the opportunities I have because of their generosity. This scholarship program holds a dear place in my heart and helps me succeed in working toward my dreams. When I was eight months old, my dad passed away while serving in the Marine Corps. My mom was left having to raise me, along with my two brothers, and it is something that I know was not easy for her. We feel blessed for the patronage we are given. The Folded Flag Foundation has helped us tremendously with my being able to attend college. At USD, I studied in a neurobiology lab, worked as a pre-health peer mentor, and was president of the Neuroscience Club! In the Fall of 2024, I plan to attend physician assistant school to become a PA. Through my experiences at the University of San Diego (USD), I am passionate about my academics and future career and highly grateful for the wonderful relationships I have formed with my peers and professors. I graduated in May of 2024, but I can only recognize this accomplishment by acknowledging the generosity that I have been supported by with Folded Flag Foundation. We are so thankful for all that you do, not only for me but also for every other child who has gone through the hardship of losing a parent.”

From 1st – 30th June, along with over 550 CEVA colleagues, I'm taking part in CEVA UKIN’s biggest-ever community fundraising initiative - #theCEVA100.

The longest walkable distance in the world, is from Cape Town in South Africa to Magadan on Russia's eastern coast. The distance stretches 14,334 miles (23,068 kilometers).
No human has ever taken such a long walk!
We are proposing to do this TWICE!
Out and Back.

So far I've clocked up 179km (111 miles) and the team has achieved 6,600 miles and counting!

The short video clip below is of my early morning walk today.

If you are able to contribute and donate in support of the Alzheimer's Society I would be very grateful - please use the link below.

https://lnkd.in/gitdZX7K

#theCEVA100 #CEVALogistics

I am so appreciative for the incredible number of supportive messages I’ve gotten this past week for being named on the Modern Healthcare list of 50 Most Influential Clinical Executives.  Thank you to Modern HC for the honor. Thank you even more to my friends and colleagues at Elevance Health, who do such inspiring work on behalf of our members and communities.

I also want to highlight some people on the list I have the good fortune of knowing and are working on some of our biggest healthcare challenges. People like Sreekanth Chaguturu, Amar A. Desai, MD, MPH, Alexander Garza, Alice Hm Chen, Dora Hughes, Dr. Omar Lateef, Vivek Murthy, Jonathan Perlin, Jaewon Ryu, Neel Shah, Bruce Siegel, and Tunde Sotunde. They are all truly great leaders and I endeavor to learn from each of them.

And — let’s be honest — there are so many worthy clinical leaders and execs not on the list this year. For all of our problems in US healthcare, a paucity of smart, thoughtful clinical leaders is not one of them. We could fill a list of the next 50 leaders, the 50 after that, and the 50 after that, and on and on. I want to thank every clinical leader I have worked with, learned from, been in awe of. You all have brought a common sense, practical view to the rooms you are in and, most importantly, have represented the patients we have gotten to care for. Thank you for that and everything you do. Keep it up, and I will try everyday to follow your example.

#Milwaukee fact: The Juneteenth Day Parade and Celebration is one of the largest and longest running #Juneteenth celebrations in the country.

I was able to commemorate the day and enjoy the parade’s 53rd year with thousands of others, including my colleagues from US Bank and one of our community leaders, Nina V.A. Johnson, MBA.

Juneteenth marks the official end of slavery in the United States. It’s a day to revisit the progress we’ve made since and to celebrate the resilience, culture, and heritage of African Americans. Let’s continue building a world where we can honor our differences and bring our whole selves to everything we do.

Pfizer is laying off employees as part of a plan to save $5.5 billion.

The same company made $53 billion in profit after releasing its covid vaccine.

How come employees pay the price during rainy days but when the sun is shining it all goes to investors and execs?

column2:
It's week two of summer break in our household. And that means we're in full swing of summer sports, camps and lake time with my three kids. My entryway is a sign of the times, piled high with Crocs, sports gear and swim goggles.

While I love summer (who doesn't in the Land of 10,000 Lakes), I have to admit it requires a serious shift in my mindset as a working parent. The mental gymnastics required to manage all the logistics of who is going where and when is real - and some days it feels like a part-time job! And don't get me started on managing the budget for ice cream, Starbucks and Culvers runs.

At Brillect, we have several (and might I add rock star) consultants who have opted to take the summers off. Some of them have done it for years; others are trying it for the first time this summer. But the common thread between all of them is that taking the summers off is a win for them, their families and our clients.

I believe that work life integration comes in all shapes, sizes and seasons. Finding that right-size role starts with listening to what people need in order to thrive at work + in life. Because there's more to us than our job titles.

We're a company made up of triathletes, pilots, pickleball fanatics, canoe craftsman and yes, parents who are juggling all the things in the busy summer season.

Some people may want the time off to care for children while others have booked a bucket list trip or want to finish a passion project.

No matter what the reason, we keep our focus on the whole person - not just the work person - to shape a career that recognizes where they're at in life.

Here's to summer and finding time for all the things that bring us joy.

#WorkLife #Summer #WorkingParent

On November 1st, I am going to retire or as I like to call it “re-mission” from Ascension.  It has been such an honor to serve the Catholic Health Ministry not once but twice in my career.  It was such a privilege to be able to bring my faith to work and not have to separate faith from profession.  I am so grateful to Ascension and its leadership for the opportunity provided to me.  My wife, Liz, and I are going to take a sabbatical and discern about how to re-mission for what we call our third-third.  We want to continue to serve our community and our faith in perhaps a different way than we have done so far.  Below is the announcement that Joe Impicciche sent out internally on my announcement.


Peter Leibold, Executive Vice President and Chief Advocacy Officer, is planning to leave Ascension on November 1. He will remain engaged with Ascension by serving as a member of the Ascension Foundation Board.  A servant leader, Peter worked diligently to advance Ascension’s Mission and was a key leader in helping our organization navigate through and beyond the COVID-19 pandemic. Advocacy worked with Finance, Legal and Operations to clear regulatory hurdles, obtain needed flexibilities and advocate for significant provider financial relief that was essential for Ascension to serve its communities and take care of its associates.  Peter joined Ascension in 2014 and led his team by emphasizing transparency, communication and results. During his tenure, he celebrated Advocacy’s role in expanding Medicaid in Oklahoma, promoting growth in supplemental payments to several of our ministries, advancing spiritual care as a supplemental Medicare benefit, and discerning with ministries how to comply with the Ethical and Religious Directives for Catholic Healthcare. Peter brought his whole self to his role, living out his deep faith by advocating for Ascension as a ministry of the church.   Peter is a member of the Ascension Leadership Team, Ascension Leadership Academy Community 4 and the Executive Ministry Leadership Formation Cohort 13.  He received the David J. Greenburg award, the highest honor provided by the American Health Law Association (AHLA) for service to the health law bar. He has served on various foundation and church boards.   Before joining Ascension, Peter served as the CEO of the AHLA for 15 years and was General Counsel of the Catholic Health Association for three years.  Peter’s departure in November provides Ascension time to identify and transition a successor.   Please join me in thanking Peter for his service to Ascension and his dedication to our Mission.

This month – and every day – I am grateful for colleagues across Optum who are dedicated to delivering a differentiated care experience for those we serve, including the LGBTQ+ community.

One such experience is the Pride+ Care program offered through Atrius Health (part of Optum). This comprehensive program takes the specialized care team’s longstanding commitment to providing personalized care a step further, integrating high-quality, adult primary care with varied specialty health services to better meet the unique needs of LGBTQ+ patients.

Each person’s needs and goals are distinct - and it is my hope that together, we continue to create more spaces and experiences in health care where everyone feels welcomed, safe, respected and heard. In honor of Pride Month, please join me in acknowledging and celebrating the diversity, histories and lived experiences of the LGBTQ+ community. #pridemonth #optumhealth

column2: I’ve loved hearing how our team members feel welcome, valued and empowered to bring their authentic selves to work at Optum and across UnitedHealth Group! Check out their stories to hear more about what Pride Month, diversity and inclusion means to our incredible team.

This month – and every day – I am grateful for colleagues across Optum who are dedicated to delivering a differentiated care experience for those we serve, including the LGBTQ+ community.

One such experience is the Pride+ Care program offered through Atrius Health (part of Optum). This comprehensive program takes the specialized care team’s longstanding commitment to providing personalized care a step further, integrating high-quality, adult primary care with varied specialty health services to better meet the unique needs of LGBTQ+ patients.

Each person’s needs and goals are distinct - and it is my hope that together, we continue to create more spaces and experiences in health care where everyone feels welcomed, safe, respected and heard. In honor of Pride Month, please join me in acknowledging and celebrating the diversity, histories and lived experiences of the LGBTQ+ community. #pridemonth #optumhealth

I'm excited to announce I've joined Sentara Health as the Executive Vice President and President of Acute Care and Post-Acute Services. This is an incredible opportunity to make a real impact on the health of our communities.

What drew me to Sentara Health is its significant system-wide growth. With a health plan and care delivery services in multiple states and plans to expand, more people can access a variety of health services, from hospitals to outpatient centers. This expansion brings top-notch care closer to home.

The One Sentara model is a game-changer for community health; by integrating health plans with care delivery, it ensures preventive services are covered and post-acute services are seamlessly included, aligning with my vision for comprehensive, community-focused care.

I'm excited to work alongside the amazing team at Sentara to enhance our services and improve patient outcomes. Together, we'll make a difference and promote a healthier future for everyone.

Thank you for your support and encouragement as I embark on this new journey.

column2:
Watching a recent ONC Certification program roundtable and realizing how directly the ONC targeted Epic/Abridge with the way they tailored "Decision support interventions" (§170.315(b)(11)) in the HTI-1 final rule.

As a reminder, Abridge is part of Epic's Vendor Services program, but specifically an elite tier (Workshop). This is reserved for:
1. Apps building something Epic does not want to build, but wants to be able to be leading in (this applies to both Toolbox and Workshop tiers)
2. Apps that Epic has chosen to codevelop the cutting edge APIs and UX to accomplish those workflows (this applies to just Workshop)

"Decision support interventions" is intended to replace an existing criteria "clinical decision support" (§ 170.315(a)(9)) to introduce information transparency to address uncertainty regarding the quality of predictive DSIs. The criteria requires surfacing "source attributes" about AI algorithms. This is an important and valuable criteria, but it is burdensome - AI is not great at sourcing, as we've seen in the news.

What's interesting is the proposed rule, this criterion applied to "developers of certified health IT with Health IT Modules that enable or interface with predictive DSIs". That's a broad range - any interfaced DSI would be somewhat looped into providing these source attributes.

In the final rule, the scope of impacted Predictive DSIs was narrowed to  "supplied by a developer of certified health IT as part of its Health IT Module "

In the webinar, it seems that language was intended to loop in Abridge and Epic:

Audience member: "The first one here is going with the NES analogy if both Game cartridges can be seen in the Nintendo store, does that imply "stewardship"? Both games can integrate with the NES APIs and Nintendo wants to show that availability is possible but only one game was developed collaboratively"
Jeff Smith (ONC): "The answer to the question is that the kind of source attribute and intervention risk management requirements would only pertain to the game that was developed collaboratively. We know several developers have App Stores but we don't consider predictive DSIs that are offered through the App Store "supplied by" unless the developer themselves have gone to promote a specific predictive DSI that they have collaboratively worked with... simply listing a predictive DSI in a developer's App Store does not mean that that predictive DSi is necessarily supplied by developer so just being in the App
Store isn't a determinative quality."

Being an EHR partner is a significant tailwind, for sure, but with that comes a required regulatory burden that competitive ambient/AI solutions are not regulated by. This is good news for ambient/AI startups trying to "fast follow" - they're hypothetically able to use the APIs Abridge and Epic create, but don't necessarily have to implement the sourcing. I wonder if health systems demand DSI for all their AI solutions, though.

column2:
Let's recap what appears to be complete BS against Trump. The man wins an election against an unpopular candidate, Hillary Clinton
. They pay for a fake dossier and claim it's not the American people who elected him but the Russians. A Special Counsel is appointed, millions of dollars are spent, and the conclusion is that there was never any collusion between Trump and the Russians. It was the American people who elected him. It was complete BS.

Once in the White House, a woman writes a memoir and claims Trump sexually assaulted her several decades ago. Trump says no, I never did what she is accusing me of. New York then changes the law so she could bring charges decades after. She's actually unable to provide any direct evidence because she waited decades to report the alleged assault. The case proceeds anyway; eventually, after back and forth, Trump has to pay her millions of dollars for defamation. In interviews, she says she can't wait to receive the money so that she can go shopping worldwide. She also says the sexual assault was never sexual; claims rape is sexy. The media ignores the inconsistencies because that's not what the so-called deep state wants.

A porn actress also comes out and says she had an affair with Trump decades ago, and Trump's lawyer paid her $130,000. The government says, wow! That's such huge information, had the American people known that they would have elected Clinton. Several people say there's no case to be made there; eventually, the case goes to court with the government claiming that he did not specifically disclose that the legal fee was somehow a campaign contribution. Anyway, they convict Trump. Meanwhile, the porn industry exploits all these women and men, paying them only a small fee once to shoot their movies and using them for decades without ever paying them any other fee. One would think a government that cares about porn actresses would try to help them and stop the exploitation. No, they actually don't care.

I can go on and on. When junior journalists receive information from the government in the form of indictments, they often believe everything the government says, that they are just there trying to punish deadly criminals in society, that they are trying to stop a dangerous guy. Meanwhile, the so-called dangerous man has not done all the atrocities others have done in terms of laws that punish ordinary people, including some based on their race, and bombs all over the world that left hundreds of thousands of people dead. Of course, Trump is not a perfect man. People attack him; he also attacks people, and so do you.

But the false claim that he's the worst American to have ever lived and that now he's akin to Adolf Hitler and if he's re-elected again, doom and gloom would envelop the United States are simply false. Now they are claiming that he's so crazy he might attack Biden on stage on June 27 when they debate in Atlanta next week. The hypocrisy is really disgusting. May God help us all.
column26: Steve Romano liked Todd Jewell, MBA’s comment on this

I'm excited to announce I've joined Sentara Health as the Executive Vice President and President of Acute Care and Post-Acute Services. This is an incredible opportunity to make a real impact on the health of our communities.

What drew me to Sentara Health is its significant system-wide growth. With a health plan and care delivery services in multiple states and plans to expand, more people can access a variety of health services, from hospitals to outpatient centers. This expansion brings top-notch care closer to home.

The One Sentara model is a game-changer for community health; by integrating health plans with care delivery, it ensures preventive services are covered and post-acute services are seamlessly included, aligning with my vision for comprehensive, community-focused care.

I'm excited to work alongside the amazing team at Sentara to enhance our services and improve patient outcomes. Together, we'll make a difference and promote a healthier future for everyone.

Thank you for your support and encouragement as I embark on this new journey.

Just yesterday, I attended an inspiring Fireside Chat at Atlas School, hosted by Aaron Smith, M.Ed. The event featured insightful discussions with industry leaders from BOK Financial, including Garrett Guthrie, CDR, Amy Brown, Brent Lewis, and Sean Medlin. It was a fantastic opportunity to network and gain insights into the future of technology and banking.

BOK Financial is a prime example of community-driven banking, with a strong focus on local initiatives in Tulsa. The speakers discussed various innovative projects, emphasizing their commitment to consumer and mobile web development. They highlighted their efforts to introduce features that distinguish them from their competitors and shared their vision for staying modern and effective over the next 15 years. Their focus on modernizing payment processes and API integration strategies, along with their proactive approach to addressing technical debt within the software engineering team, was impressive as well. I value how they highlighted the significance of both soft and technical skills, emphasizing that it goes beyond memorization.

I'm thankful for the chance to attend a school that helps forge connections with top companies like BOK Financial in the Tulsa tech scene. Their groundbreaking work in banking technology truly inspires me, and I appreciate the opportunity to learn more about their company.

#AtlasSchool #Networking #BOKFinancial #Software #CyberSecurity #TechInnovation

Understanding what motivates us is an important driver for the decisions we take and the way we view great opportunities that come our way. I have been - and am - very lucky to have a situation where my personal development goals, the business needs and personal drivers have been taken into consideration.

Whilst I will be leaving a fantastic team of highly competent, resilient and humble leaders who have shown up with a can-do, people-orientated spirit and have taught me so much, I am thrilled to share that I am starting a new role as President of the Asia Pacific, Middle East and Africa (APMA) Region for #Novartis! After 14 years of working across the Nordic countries, and also in Japan and Switzerland, I am coming home to my roots

I have a busy couple of months ahead – I’ll be familiarizing myself with my new home – Singapore, getting to know my tremendous new team, and understanding our opportunities and challenges.

I’ve been impressed by the warmth of the welcome I have received so far and the ‘One Team’ mindset across the region; when they move as one, they are simply unstoppable!

It won’t be long before I visit our key markets, and I am excited to connect with colleagues and stakeholders to understand how we can work together and continue to add value to the patients we serve around APMA!

I am deeply pleased to share that I have graduated from the ITSMF - Information Technology Senior Management Forum Management Academy. My profound gratitude goes to Bank of America for the unwavering investment in my professional development. This support not only enhances my capabilities but also inspires me to contribute more meaningfully each day to my teammates and the community in which we live and work.

The ITSMF Management Academy offers Black IT leaders a truly transformative journey. Over the past ten months, alongside my 76 cohort members—affectionately known as the Phoenix 76—we embarked on an intense and immersive experience that underscored ITSMF's mission to transform the mind, body, and soul. Through 26 assignments, over ten book readings, executive and book presentations, leader-to-leader sessions, and monthly cohort calls, our directors, Dr Turner and Shakeer Abdullah, Ph.D. challenged us to lead ourselves first before leading others. Their dedication delivered a leadership program that was both rigorous and methodical, transforming us from the inside out. One particularly impactful aspect was the unfiltered feedback, which was both constructive and compassionate.

To cap it off, I was humbled to receive the ITSMF Global Citizenship Award. This honor fuels my resolve and inspires me to continue showing up selflessly for those around me.

I would like to honor a few individuals who made this experience unforgettable:

• My leader, Terrelle Carswell has been my staunch advocate throughout this journey. His support, advocacy, and encouragement have been invaluable.

• My accountability partner in the program, Zena Kyles, MBA, PMP, epitomizes strength and resolve. She taught me to put aside excuses and simply show up.

• My executive mentor, Tonya Bryant, challenged me to aim high. Her encouragement to continually pursue growth and learning was invaluable.

To my Phoenix 76 family: Our ten-month metamorphosis required us to trust the process. We finished strong because we learned to humbly sharpen each other to excel and thrive. Our journey to the elevated altitude didn't leave us gasping for air; instead, we learned to release our burdens and blind spots so we could soar like the Phoenix. As we've reached this mountainous milestone, remember, we were not meant to stay at the top. The real work is just beginning. As John Maxwell wisely said, "We didn't get this far, to only get this far."

Watching a recent ONC Certification program roundtable and realizing how directly the ONC targeted Epic/Abridge with the way they tailored "Decision support interventions" (§170.315(b)(11)) in the HTI-1 final rule.

As a reminder, Abridge is part of Epic's Vendor Services program, but specifically an elite tier (Workshop). This is reserved for:
1. Apps building something Epic does not want to build, but wants to be able to be leading in (this applies to both Toolbox and Workshop tiers)
2. Apps that Epic has chosen to codevelop the cutting edge APIs and UX to accomplish those workflows (this applies to just Workshop)

"Decision support interventions" is intended to replace an existing criteria "clinical decision support" (§ 170.315(a)(9)) to introduce information transparency to address uncertainty regarding the quality of predictive DSIs. The criteria requires surfacing "source attributes" about AI algorithms. This is an important and valuable criteria, but it is burdensome - AI is not great at sourcing, as we've seen in the news.

What's interesting is the proposed rule, this criterion applied to "developers of certified health IT with Health IT Modules that enable or interface with predictive DSIs". That's a broad range - any interfaced DSI would be somewhat looped into providing these source attributes.

In the final rule, the scope of impacted Predictive DSIs was narrowed to  "supplied by a developer of certified health IT as part of its Health IT Module "

In the webinar, it seems that language was intended to loop in Abridge and Epic:

Audience member: "The first one here is going with the NES analogy if both Game cartridges can be seen in the Nintendo store, does that imply "stewardship"? Both games can integrate with the NES APIs and Nintendo wants to show that availability is possible but only one game was developed collaboratively"
Jeff Smith (ONC): "The answer to the question is that the kind of source attribute and intervention risk management requirements would only pertain to the game that was developed collaboratively. We know several developers have App Stores but we don't consider predictive DSIs that are offered through the App Store "supplied by" unless the developer themselves have gone to promote a specific predictive DSI that they have collaboratively worked with... simply listing a predictive DSI in a developer's App Store does not mean that that predictive DSi is necessarily supplied by developer so just being in the App
Store isn't a determinative quality."

Being an EHR partner is a significant tailwind, for sure, but with that comes a required regulatory burden that competitive ambient/AI solutions are not regulated by. This is good news for ambient/AI startups trying to "fast follow" - they're hypothetically able to use the APIs Abridge and Epic create, but don't necessarily have to implement the sourcing. I wonder if health systems demand DSI for all their AI solutions, though.

column2:
🌟 Exciting Times at Atlas School! 🌟

I recently had the privilege of attending a fireside chat at Atlas School, hosted by Aaron Smith, M.Ed. and featuring insightful discussions with industry leaders from BOK Financial: Garrett Guthrie, CDR, Amy Brown, Brent Lewis, and Sean Medlin. This event was a fantastic opportunity to network and learn about the future of technology and banking.

Key Takeaways:

🏦 Community-Driven Banking: The speakers highlighted the importance of local initiatives, starting right here in Tulsa.

🚀 Innovative Projects: From supporting consumer and mobile web development to introducing new features that set them apart from competitors, the focus is on staying modern and effective over the next 10-15 years. Critical milestones include the modernization of payment infrastructure and addressing technical debt within the software engineering team.

🏢 Data Center Modernization: A significant three-year initiative to modernize data centers.

🛡️ Challenges:

#Cybersecurity: Developers are being trained in secure coding practices, making cybersecurity the top priority across the bank.

#FraudDetection: Dedicated teams are continuously monitoring for fraudulent activities.

#AIUtilization: Emphasizing the responsible use of AI.

🛠️ Skills Focus:

Technical Skills: Importance of real #problemSolving skills in technical interviews, rather than mere memorization.

Soft Skills: Not to be overlooked, with a focus on #authenticity and the ability to #mentor the next generation.

💼 Interview Insights:

Constantly evaluate if the role is the right fit, treating the interview process as a two-way street.

Success in the first 60-90 days involves building relationships.

🔥 This event was an incredible learning experience, and I am grateful for the opportunity to connect with such inspiring professionals from BOK Financial. A big thank you to the Career Services department for organizing this insightful session. Looking forward to applying these insights in my own career journey!

#Networking #FiresideChat #TechInnovation #Cybersecurity #CareerGrowth #AtlasSchool #CommunityBanking #BOKFinancial

“The world is a university and everyone in it is a teacher. Make sure when you wake up in the morning, you go to school.”

That’s exactly what we do at Brink’s Inc inc. We are building a culture to be a life long student, we learn everyday, become better everyday and are building the community that is winning together for the common goals.

As the executive sponsor of ASPIRE, Brink’s Asian American Pacific Islander ERG along with Vinti Gupta as the Chair of ASPIRE, past week we had the great honor to learn from our special guest Anne Chow (She/Her), who as a business leader and a trail blazer is making an impact over three decades at the intersection of people, culture, and technology. Some of her nuggets of wisdom that touched our hearts:

1. #Education is a great equalizer
2. #Be YOUR best everyday
3. Have a deep passion for #Service
4. Every business is a #people business
5. #Leadership is the calling. Leadership is a choice & it transcends.
5. Biggest superpower is #YOU. Be your own authentic self every minute of the day.
6. #Culture is your competitive advantage. It's what in the halls and not what's on the walls.
7. #Lead bigger, lead inclusively. World needs #InclusiveLeadership today!

Thank you Anne Chow for lifting us yet again. I have greatly enjoyed reading your book: The Leader’s Guide to Unconscious Bias and can not wait to read your new upcoming book LEAD BIGGER.

column2:
This is a powerful lesson in confidence and grace from my ten-year-old.

A lot of times we learn something from our children and this is one of them. My ten year old daughter at school was told that “you are ugly” by a girl leading a group of other girls.

I was upset and broken down for a second with lot of thoughts hitting my head until she continued her remaining conversation…

My girl instantly responded that yes “I’m trying to look like you today“ and the other girl got mad and said that “I can’t stand you anymore” And my girl said “then please sit down”.

As a parent it hurts me still writing about it and at the same time I’m proud that my daughter chose to be kind, confident and resilient to harsh words.

 #confidence #kindness #resilience #uplift
column23: This is so amazing on so many levels! Hats off to your daughter for standing up for herself! She is going to be one strong independent girl just like her Mom!

As a founder, I often get asked – how did you come up with your company name?   While I typically use this to crack some dumb dad-joke, the reality is the name will find you.

When we named XUP (pronounced ‘zup’), it was after whiteboarding up a thousand plus names, multiple languages and meanings…but what really happened is someone was being funny and then an unfortunate spelling mistake that led to the name. Eventually, we came up with the ‘public’ story which was the “X” stood for transactions and we drive them UP! So XUP!

Now that we’re on to pAIwares (pronounced pay-wares), it was MUCH easier. We knew AI was going to be on the platform, we were software and in payments…so after a few URL availability searches, pAIwares.com was available and it stuck. Okay, we had one teammate who didn’t like it, but he eventually came around.

Some say naming your company is exciting while others say it’s daunting. Either way, pick one that you can get behind with an available URL, and don’t be afraid of people not pronouncing it correctly. As long as they’re calling you something close, you’re in the game.

How about your company - how did you choose your name?  Comment below - curious about everyone's experiences!

column2: Come to work with an outstanding networking team and leaders Islam Sallaj aka Izzy and Scott E. at Roswell Park Comprehensive Cancer Center ! This is an opportunity to professionally shine while serving a remarkable mission of hope and cure!

We're partnering with Carilion Clinic for their CISO executive search. 

The CISO is a key member of the SVP/CIO's senior leadership team, responsible for maturing and overseeing a comprehensive information technology security program across the enterprise.

Reporting directly to the CIO, this position offers a unique opportunity to lead the organization’s long-term information security strategies, ensuring the protection of network, computer, device, application, and data assets. 

Carilion Clinic includes a comprehensive network of 250+ locations (from Shenandoah and the Highlands to southwest Virginia) that include hospitals, primary and specialty physician practices, and other complementary services. 

The CISO needs to reside in or relocate to Roanoke. The cybersecurity team primarily works on-site and the CISO will need to be on-site a part of each work week.

Learn more about this exciting opportunity: https://loom.ly/djvOiK8


#recruiting #jobpostings #networking

column2:
UW Health's Director of Digital Health Technology – Mobile Front Door position is a great opportunity to grow the organization's digital strategy and advance the use of mobile technologies to engage with patients, consumers, and providers.

The Director will oversee the delivery of several digital health services including:

• Mobile engagement platform
• Mobile applications
• Customer data lakehouse
• Intelligent automation
• Machine learning algorithms

UW Health is an integrated health system with a total of nine hospitals (six main hospitals, one joint operating agreement hospital,  and two hospitals within the main Illinois hospital), and four medical centers in Wisconsin and Illinois. UW Health is affiliated with the University of Wisconsin–Madison. 

Please note: The Director needs to reside in or relocate to Madison, WI. While this is a hybrid position, this individual will need to be on-site the first and third weeks of the month.

The office environment is designed as a collaborative workspace with desk hoteling, a variety of team workspaces, treadmill workstations, natural light and colorful aesthetics, and flexible eating areas.

Learn more and apply: https://loom.ly/8faWNow


#recruiting #jobpostings #networking
column26: George T ‘Buddy’ Hickman, CDH-E, CHCIO, LCHiME, FCHiME, LFHiMSS reposted this

column2:
Join the team at UW Health as their Director of Human Resources Information Systems. 

UW Health is an integrated health system with a total of nine hospitals and four medical centers in Wisconsin and Illinois. They are affiliated with the University of Wisconsin–Madison.

Reporting to the VP of HR Operations, the Director will lead a team of 11 direct reports. 

The Director will play a strategic leadership role in shaping the HR technology ecosystem and will have the opportunity to lead transformative HR technology initiatives, including:

- Oracle Cloud implementation and optimization across UW Health’s Wisconsin and Northern Illinois locations
- Expansion of the ServiceNow platform within Human Resources
- Exploring AI and generative AI for HR processes
- Ensuring compliance and evolution of HRIS systems as technologies change

The position is remote with the expectation to be onsite once a quarter.

Successful leaders in this role will have excellent communication and negotiation skills, along with strong project management and vendor management abilities.  They also need to be innovative, collaborative, and able to thrive in a fast-paced environment.

 Learn more: https://loom.ly/v7-i-P8

column2:
🌟 Exciting News! 🌟

I am thrilled to share that the Board of Directors of the Healthcare Information and Management Systems Society (HIMSS) has approved my application for advancement to Fellow Member status!

This prestigious honor is a recognition of my service, professional participation, job experience, publications, and presentations within the healthcare information and management systems field. I am deeply grateful for this acknowledgment and for the support of my colleagues, mentors, and the entire HIMSS community.

This milestone would not have been possible without the collaborative spirit and shared dedication of the incredible teams and professionals I have had the privilege to work with throughout my career. Your partnership and encouragement have been instrumental in this journey.

Thank you, HIMSS, for this honor and for inspiring me to strive for greater heights. I look forward to continuing to serve our society and our profession with the same passion, enthusiasm, and commitment to excellence. Together, we can make a significant impact on the future of healthcare.

#HIMSS #HealthcareIT #FellowMember #ProfessionalGrowth #HealthcareInnovation #Gratitude #CareerMilestone

Congratulations to Buddy Hickman, Chief Digital and Information Officer, on being named to Becker's Healthcare Hospital Review’s 133 CIO’s to Know list. 

A past board chair for both CHIME and HIMSS, Hickman joined Roswell Park in January. Already, he and his team have delivered a major enterprise network upgrade to benefit patients, clinicians and researchers. 

An industry speaker, author and mentor in the digital health leadership sphere, Hickman has served the health industry as a CIO for more than two decades, including roles at Ernst & Young and PWC.

column2:
I reached the finish line! I’m a proud Kellogg MBA!

This past weekend, I officially achieved my goal of pursuing an MBA. Over the past two years, I've expanded my toolkit with new frameworks, perspectives, experiences, friendships, and significant personal and professional growth. This experience exceeded all the expectations I had imagined.

I couldn't have made this possible without the unwavering support of my husband, Dave Russ, MBA, CPA, and my children, Hannah and Michael. I also want to thank my incredible study group, the Lakeshore Legends: Dylan Buckley, Ritu Thomas, Tom Riley, Manoj Arigela, Thomas Zukowski, MD, MBA, and Ram Ananthakrishnan. A big thanks to my family, friends, and the amazing Northwestern University - Kellogg School of Management faculty and staff.

Here's to making a lasting positive impact in the healthcare ecosystem, driven by the unique perspective of a physical therapist with an MBA!

#KelloggLeader #EMBA #LowEgoHighImpact #BeIntentional #BeThoughtful #KSM24 #LifeExperience #KelloggHealthcare

column2:
Looking back at her teenaged self when she had been recently diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), Emily Browne she says she was the direct beneficiary of the advances St. Jude has made in methotrexate pharmacodynamics and the pursuit to replace cranial radiation with intrathecal therapy. Now two decades into her career at St. Jude and nearly 29 years since her diagnosis, Browne shares her story in honor of National Cancer Survivors Day. 

“I didn’t know it then, but my journey to St. Jude began September 11, 1995, when I was diagnosed,” she says. “As a 17-year-old, I didn’t know what “oncology” meant, only that my pediatrician was concerned about my lab results and persistent fever. I found myself in a clinic in my hometown of Birmingham surrounded by children with cancer, oblivious to the fact that I was about to become one of them.” 

Fast forward and Browne began in a dream job in a clinic at St. Jude. It was then she began to understand and appreciate the enormous impact that St. Jude researchers like Dr. Ching-Hong Pui and countless others had on advancing the cure rates and improving the quality of life of all children with cancer, including herself. Over the past 20 years, she has worked in a variety of capacities at Jude – from Leukemia & Lymphoma to nursing, and now the Transition Oncology Program.  As director of the fledgling program, Browne offers her perspective, knowledge and experience to better understand the psychosocial and physical health needs of patients and families as they transition off cancer-directed therapy and for the next few years of early survivorship. 

“It’s been amazing to experience different career paths without ever leaving St. Jude,” she says, “I can’t imagine working anywhere else!” 

Today we celebrate Emily Browne and other cancer survivors around the country and inspire those recently diagnosed.
It was a great “work week” because we went live with “Workday”! Special thanks to everyone that made this historical moment happen! Stay tuned for an “Epic” day coming in October!😉

Congratulations to Pat Keel, EVP-Chief Administrative and Financial Officer, for being honored on the Becker’s Healthcare 2024 “CFOs to know” list. The annual list recognizes leaders for health systems and hospitals throughout the U.S. who are instrumental in strategic financial planning, expansions and joint ventures for their institutions and are key to the organization’s overall success. 

Keel has served as CFO for St. Jude since 2016 and was promoted to her current role in 2020. Overseeing multiple departments, her responsibilities include managing finance, supply chain, reimbursements, revenue cycle, managed care contracting and grants. 

She was instrumental in the formation and implementation of Women in Leadership & Learning program, the development of St. Jude Global's regional hubs, Workday implementation and go-live, and assisted in the overall implementation of the institution’s six-year strategic plan. 

Thank you, Pat, for all you do to keep St. Jude striving for new heights. 

#StJude #Hospital #Finance

Wow, two years at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital. Working at St. Jude as its director of internal communication has been the most rewarding and challenging (in a good way) experience of my career. I have never worked for an institution that is so laser focused on its mission and culture. The strategic planning of St. Jude and our Strategic Communication, Education and Outreach (SCEO) team is also world class and guides me every day. Cheers to our bright future, my internal communication team (you rock) and many more years of elevating the employee experience at St. Jude.

Looking back at her teenaged self when she had been recently diagnosed with acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), Emily Browne she says she was the direct beneficiary of the advances St. Jude has made in methotrexate pharmacodynamics and the pursuit to replace cranial radiation with intrathecal therapy. Now two decades into her career at St. Jude and nearly 29 years since her diagnosis, Browne shares her story in honor of National Cancer Survivors Day. 

“I didn’t know it then, but my journey to St. Jude began September 11, 1995, when I was diagnosed,” she says. “As a 17-year-old, I didn’t know what “oncology” meant, only that my pediatrician was concerned about my lab results and persistent fever. I found myself in a clinic in my hometown of Birmingham surrounded by children with cancer, oblivious to the fact that I was about to become one of them.” 

Fast forward and Browne began in a dream job in a clinic at St. Jude. It was then she began to understand and appreciate the enormous impact that St. Jude researchers like Dr. Ching-Hong Pui and countless others had on advancing the cure rates and improving the quality of life of all children with cancer, including herself. Over the past 20 years, she has worked in a variety of capacities at Jude – from Leukemia & Lymphoma to nursing, and now the Transition Oncology Program.  As director of the fledgling program, Browne offers her perspective, knowledge and experience to better understand the psychosocial and physical health needs of patients and families as they transition off cancer-directed therapy and for the next few years of early survivorship. 

“It’s been amazing to experience different career paths without ever leaving St. Jude,” she says, “I can’t imagine working anywhere else!” 

Today we celebrate Emily Browne and other cancer survivors around the country and inspire those recently diagnosed.
I’m happy to share that I’m starting a new position as Sr. Mgr-High Performance Computing at St. Jude Children's Research Hospital!

I'm absolutely thrilled 🎉 to have joined Children's National Hospital as Chief Data and AI Officer! This is such an exciting opportunity, and I can't wait to dive into this role.

I'm really looking forward to working alongside the incredible team at Children's along with Matt MacVey, MBA, MS, Jessica Herstek, Nathan Lesser, @Amy Quinn, Edward Fisher, Christopher Bott, MHA, Trecia Landrum MPA, MBA, FACHE, @Kayla Jordan, Tyler Griffin, Adam Sears, Brandon Smith, Hiroki Morizono, @Julie Nelson, Catherine Pearcy, Rachel Selekman, Todd Kirby, Alyn S., Leslie Burpo, MHA, MBA, Jessica Henthorn, Carl Dolezal and so many others, to drive innovation and leverage cutting-edge data and AI technologies 💻🤖 to improve the patient experience and outcomes. As a leading pediatric healthcare system, Children's National is excited to leverage data-driven insights, and I'm honored to be a part of that mission.

In this role, I'll be focused on developing robust data strategies, implementing advanced analytics and AI, and empowering clinicians and researchers with the tools they need to deliver the best possible experience for young patients and their families. It's an incredible opportunity, and I can't wait to contribute to the mission! 

If you're interested in learning more about the work we're doing at @Children's National, please reach out. I'd be happy to connect! #ChildrensNational #NewRole #DataAndAI #HealthcareTech #CDAIO

Tomorrow I retire from UTMB.

It has been my privilege to work with an amazing team at UTMB all focused on a compelling mission in support of education, research and BEST patient CARE.

I have been fortunate in my 44 year career to work at this wonderful Essential Hospital and AMC as well as at UVA , YNHH and Newport Hospital.  All these organizations have allowed me to be work and be true to my personal values.

My thanks and deepest appreciation to those who supported me from my earliest days as a Nuclear Medicine Technologist and then who supported my further education and experiences. 

My special thanks to those wonderful colleagues who I worked to my best ability to support and hopefully allowed you as well to realize your aspirations. 

Healthcare has been a challenging but rewarding career as has been the consummate team sport. My thanks to everyone who’s team that I have been fortunate to be a part of.

Thanks UTMB and all the team for allowing me to complete my journey with you.  What a great way to close this chapter. Your history is storied and your future is strong.

Quick question for food enthusiasts, travellers and historians: What food do you associate with Thailand cuisine, and Malaysian cuisine? (Pad Thai vs Laksa? Pad See Ew vs Char Kuey Teow?) Hold on to those thoughts because in this article for Eater, I highlight how there are parts of Thailand and Malaysia where food is not as distinct or mutually exclusive because of the shared cultures.
God Bless America. Have a wonderful Memorial Weekend. Please thank our veterans. Too many gave the ultimate sacrifice. My father (SOF), thankfully, came home.

column2:
Today is an exciting day for Saint Alphonsus and our community!

We are so proud to announce David McFadyen, MBA, FACHE as the new president and chief executive officer of Trinity Health, West Region.

David has been a leading voice in the Treasure Valley’s healthcare landscape for nearly 20 years, and since 2020, he has served as the President of Saint Alphonsus Regional Medical Center where his leadership, commitment to civic engagement, and community service have helped bring mission-driven growth to our colleagues, providers, and patients.

“I look forward to continuing the legacy that Odette Bolano has paved for the Idaho, Oregon and California region," David shared today. 

"Over the last four years, we have navigated through a global pandemic, endured the post-pandemic aftershock and despite this, have refined fiscal and operational efficiencies, and developed our service lines to reach extraordinary levels. 
With this solid foundation, I look forward to continuing to work with our medical staff, leaders, and colleagues to continue transforming healthcare, keeping quality health care local, and making it accessible for our communities.”

David will begin his new role on July 1st and looks forward to building on the health system’s legacy of compassionate, transformative health care.

Learn more about David and this exciting announcement at

column2:
The past 13 months at Flatiron Health has been amazing. Even after 25 years in the industry, I learned a ton and have met and collaborated with some amazing folks here.” Although it has been a joy creating and driving the Scientific Engagement team at Flatiron, I have chosen to step away at this time. There are a handful of factors, but the driving decision was a combination of some parental health issues that I’d like to actively help support through the next few months (hopefully to stabilization) and the fact that it aligned with some strategic Flatiron objectives in their timeline. What I’m really going to miss most is the day-to-day work with Eric Meadows Jenna Collins Craig Serra and Kristi M. Zimmerman Savill, but it’s a small world and I have a feeling we’ll all cross paths again. I also want to especially thank Javier Jimenez and Stephanie Reisinger for bringing me into the Flatiron team - this was a tremendous experience. I also want to thank the Executive team, and especially Nathan Hubbard, for allowing me to help shape the Flatiron scientific structure and ensuring that all these critical decisions supported Flatiron’s optimal path forward. 

I plan to take the month or two off from full-time Epidemiology work and instead, roll up my sleeves to provide some caregiving to my parents and hopefully also give my kids more of my time than they probably even want this summer and helping to develop some good core memories. 

In a perfect world, I will be looking to jump back into full-time work by mid/late August (hopefully in time to attend ISPE) and I’m absolutely open to discussion on what that work might be (epidemiology, data strategy, drug safety, CSO, etc.) as I do not have anything definitely lined up for my next role.

If you have any ideas or want to talk about how I may be able to help you/your organization, I'm all ears.  I look forward to speaking to many of you soon!

#DIA 👏😎Fantastic day 1 in San Diego! 
Great to meet my US colleagues Brett Huselton Joe Devine Eric Hauser Anthony W. Luttenberger Aya S. Ryann Baudin Nathan Thompson Amber Frasketi JB Flinders, PhD, MBA and our CEO Bekki Bracken Brown looking forward to catching up with everyone on day 2 🧍‍♀️🧍🧍‍♂️
UBC

Meet Antoinette Messulam-Defaux. She has worked in Pharmacovigilance since 2011, leading all aspects of clinical trials, post-marketing, and medical device safety.  In her current role as Associate Director, Global Case Processing, she coordinates PV system set up, ensuring a seamless transition of PV activities and data migration into the UBC safety database.  Click here to learn more. https://hubs.li/Q02y98Xd0

Have you considered incorporating RWD/RWE in your integrated evidence strategy? The recent FDA draft guidance on confirmatory evidence paves the way for the inclusion of RWD/RWE to support drug effectiveness studies. Partner with UBC to develop an evidence generation strategy that can improve regulatory review to help bring safe and effective treatments to patients. Download our white paper to learn more: https://hubs.li/Q02xX_920

#PatientsFirst #RWE #RealWorldEvidence #RWD #RealWorldData

A few weeks ago I spent the day at Virginia Mason Medical Center in Seattle. Hearing directly from our team members always brings terrific insights. On this particular day we toured the VMMC family birth center, which is a beautiful state-of-the-art facility, funded in part by our Foundation, thanks to generous community donors. John Oppenheimer, VMFH Foundation Co-Chair, and I are grateful to everyone at VMMC for spending time with us.

After 11 incredible years, the time has come for me to say goodbye to Franciscan Inpatient Team at Virginia Mason Franciscan Health. This transition has been a time for me to reflect on my journey and be grateful for the opportunities and relationships I have had on my way!

The camaraderie I've received from my colleagues has been instrumental in my professional and personal development. Together, we have navigated challenges, celebrated successes, and continually strived to provide the highest quality of care to our patients. 

I want to extend my heartfelt thanks to every team member, colleague and friend I've had the privilege of working with. Your collaboration, and encouragement have made me a better clinician, leader and person.

As I embark on this new chapter, I carry with me the lessons learned and the friendships formed at St Joseph Medical Center and VMFH. While leaving is bittersweet, I am excited for what the future holds and confident that the foundation built here will continue to support my growth.

I look forward to staying connected and cheering on your continued success from afar.

Aparna Ananth MD, MBA Timothy O'Haver, MHA, LFACHE Matthew Metsker PA-C, MPAS, MHA Ashwin Shivakumar, MD, MSPH, SFHM, FACP, CPE Jennifer Schomburg Thérèse Franco, MD Evan Coates Darcy Leaman, MBA, CPRP Ruth Flint Kim Moore Thomas Frederickson, MD, FACP, SFHM, MBA Laura B Webster

It’s so easy to forget to take care of one of our most valuable assets: mental health. 

When we think of wealth we think about money. But money loses its luster if we’re not also rich in health.

My husband purchased this book a while back and we’ve tried to read one page of "The Daily Dad" each night. That’s the concept of the book, to read a page a day for lessons and reminders about parenting. Yesterday's passage was about protecting wealth — not in dollars, but mental wealth. It was a great reminder that all the hard work that we do won’t matter if we’re drained and mentally exhausted. We can’t show up for our kids, for others, or ourselves if we’re not in good health. 

So, as you start your Wednesday, here’s a cheers to wealth - in all forms!

Recently, I sat down to talk with lots of women about their financial journey and many of the conversations led to what they wished they would have known sooner. 

Reflecting on my own financial journey, I realize now how much small changes can make a huge difference. It's something I wish I had known sooner! From not saving early enough to feeling too embarrassed to ask questions, these are common regrets I've heard from so many women.

In my latest blog post, I share insights from my own experiences and interviews with amazing women. Whether it's understanding tax-deferred savings, leveraging work benefits, or just getting more involved in your finances, there's always room for improvement.

Here's the full blog post with some ideas on how to move forward to start making better decisions today:

I have been deeply moved by the outpouring of support the organization, my team, and I have received over the past month. I’m overwhelmed by all the heartfelt messages, phone calls, and kindness from friends and colleagues, as well as the lamenting by patients at the loss of the Walmart Health Care Access Point. I joked with Morgan that I think I’ve heard from everyone I’ve ever met at this point.

Since we announced the closure of Walmart Health, I’ve sat down many times to write my thoughts.

Yesterday, some of my team spent time together in person for likely the last time. Through all the noise, the core message is clear. This is how I will remember Walmart Health: the patients we served, the impact we had in our communities, the vision of what nationally scalable, accessible, and high-quality healthcare could look like, the incredible talent brought to bear, and the lasting friendships.

Joseph Addison wrote, “We cannot insure success, but we can deserve it.” I’m looking forward to seeing the great things everyone will go on to do and the problems this team will solve.

Excited to talk mental health with Zeera's Chief Clinical Officer, Rachel Hoffman, PhD, focused on a topic that is too-often neglected: the mental health of deskless workers. From truck drivers and manufacturing employees, to store associates and hospitality workers, deskless workers make up 80% of our global workforce and face high rates of mental illness, yet have remarkably poor access to care.

🌀 Research shows that mistreatment by customers — something that 62% of restaurant employees experienced in 2021 alone — drives burn out and leads to mental illness.
🌀 BIPOC make up 40% of retail workers — but our country’s therapist population can only support 1.7% of people of color in America.

And yet, the availability of mental health benefits is far rarer for deskless workers—and even when mental health benefits are available to deskless workers, they completely miss the mark, failing to support the unique needs, schedules and culture of deskless employees.

Join us this June to talk through how we can solve the problem together ✨ Register here: https://lnkd.in/gAZtcEeW
